Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Can you tell me, Socrates, whether virtue is acquired by teaching or by practice; or if neither by teaching nor by practice, then whether it comes to man by nature, or in what other way?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: O Meno, there was a time when the Thessalians were famous among the other Hellenes only for their riches and their riding; but now, if I am not mistaken, they are equally famous for their wisdom, especially at Larisa, which is the native city of your friend Aristippus. And this is Gorgias' doing; for when he came there, the flower of the Aleuadae, among them your admirer Aristippus, and the other chiefs of the Thessalians, fell in love with his wisdom. And he has taught you the habit of answering questions in a grand and bold style, which becomes those who know, and is the style in which he himself answers all comers; and any Hellene who likes may ask him anything. How different is our lot! my dear Meno. Here at Athens there is a dearth of the commodity, and all wisdom seems to have emigrated from us to you. I am certain that if you were to ask any Athenian whether virtue was natural or acquired, he would laugh in your face, and say: 'Stranger, you have far too good an opinion of me, if you think that I can answer your question. For I literally do not know what virtue is, and much less whether it is acquired by teaching or not.' And I myself, Meno, living as I do in this region of poverty, am as poor as the rest of the world; and I confess with shame that I know literally nothing about virtue; and when I do not know the 'quid' of anything how can I know the 'quale'? How, if I knew nothing at all of Meno, could I tell if he was fair, or the opposite of fair; rich and noble, or the reverse of rich and noble? Do you think that I could?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: No, indeed. But are you in earnest, Socrates, in saying that you do not know what virtue is? And am I to carry back this report of you to Thessaly?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Not only that, my dear boy, but you may say further that I have never known of any one else who did, in my judgment.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Then you have never met Gorgias when he was at Athens?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, I have.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: And did you not think that he knew?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have not a good memory, Meno, and therefore I cannot now tell what I thought of him at the time. And I dare say that he did know, and that you know what he said: please, therefore, to remind me of what he said; or, if you would rather, tell me your own view; for I suspect that you and he think much alike.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then as he is not here, never mind him, and do you tell me: By the gods, Meno, be generous, and tell me what you say that virtue is; for I shall be truly delighted to find that I have been mistaken, and that you and Gorgias do really have this knowledge; although I have been just saying that I have never found anybody who had.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There will be no difficulty, Socrates, in answering your question. Let us take first the virtue of a man--he should know how to administer the state, and in the administration of it to benefit his friends and harm his enemies; and he must also be careful not to suffer harm himself. A woman's virtue, if you wish to know about that, may also be easily described: her duty is to order her house, and keep what is indoors, and obey her husband. Every age, every condition of life, young or old, male or female, bond or free, has a different virtue: there are virtues numberless, and no lack of definitions of them; for virtue is relative to the actions and ages of each of us in all that we do. And the same may be said of vice, Socrates (Compare Arist. Pol.).

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: How fortunate I am, Meno! When I ask you for one virtue, you present me with a swarm of them (Compare Theaet.), which are in your keeping. Suppose that I carry on the figure of the swarm, and ask of you, What is the nature of the bee? and you answer that there are many kinds of bees, and I reply: But do bees differ as bees, because there are many and different kinds of them; or are they not rather to be distinguished by some other quality, as for example beauty, size, or shape? How would you answer me?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should answer that bees do not differ from one another, as bees.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if I went on to say: That is what I desire to know, Meno; tell me what is the quality in which they do not differ, but are all alike;--would you be able to answer?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And so of the virtues, however many and different they may be, they have all a common nature which makes them virtues; and on this he who would answer the question, 'What is virtue?' would do well to have his eye fixed: Do you understand?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I am beginning to understand; but I do not as yet take hold of the question as I could wish.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When you say, Meno, that there is one virtue of a man, another of a woman, another of a child, and so on, does this apply only to virtue, or would you say the same of health, and size, and strength? Or is the nature of health always the same, whether in man or woman?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should say that health is the same, both in man and woman.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not this true of size and strength? If a woman is strong, she will be strong by reason of the same form and of the same strength subsisting in her which there is in the man. I mean to say that strength, as strength, whether of man or woman, is the same. Is there any difference?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And will not virtue, as virtue, be the same, whether in a child or in a grown-up person, in a woman or in a man?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I cannot help feeling, Socrates, that this case is different from the others.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But why? Were you not saying that the virtue of a man was to order a state, and the virtue of a woman was to order a house?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I did say so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can either house or state or anything be well ordered without temperance and without justice?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then they who order a state or a house temperately or justly order them with temperance and justice?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then both men and women, if they are to be good men and women, must have the same virtues of temperance and justice?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can either a young man or an elder one be good, if they are intemperate and unjust?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: They cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: They must be temperate and just?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then all men are good in the same way, and by participation in the same virtues?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Such is the inference.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they surely would not have been good in the same way, unless their virtue had been the same?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: They would not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now that the sameness of all virtue has been proven, try and remember what you and Gorgias say that virtue is.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Will you have one definition of them all?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That is what I am seeking.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: If you want to have one definition of them all, I know not what to say, but that virtue is the power of governing mankind.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does this definition of virtue include all virtue? Is virtue the same in a child and in a slave, Meno? Can the child govern his father, or the slave his master; and would he who governed be any longer a slave?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No, indeed; there would be small reason in that. Yet once more, fair friend; according to you, virtue is 'the power of governing;' but do you not add 'justly and not unjustly'?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates; I agree there; for justice is virtue.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Would you say 'virtue,' Meno, or 'a virtue'?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean as I might say about anything; that a round, for example, is 'a figure' and not simply 'figure,' and I should adopt this mode of speaking, because there are other figures.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Quite right; and that is just what I am saying about virtue--that there are other virtues as well as justice.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What are they? tell me the names of them, as I would tell you the names of the other figures if you asked me.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Courage and temperance and wisdom and magnanimity are virtues; and there are many others.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, Meno; and again we are in the same case: in searching after one virtue we have found many, though not in the same way as before; but we have been unable to find the common virtue which runs through them all.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why, Socrates, even now I am not able to follow you in the attempt to get at one common notion of virtue as of other things.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No wonder; but I will try to get nearer if I can, for you know that all things have a common notion. Suppose now that some one asked you the question which I asked before: Meno, he would say, what is figure? And if you answered 'roundness,' he would reply to you, in my way of speaking, by asking whether you would say that roundness is 'figure' or 'a figure;' and you would answer 'a figure.'

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And for this reason--that there are other figures?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if he proceeded to ask, What other figures are there? you would have told him.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if he similarly asked what colour is, and you answered whiteness, and the questioner rejoined, Would you say that whiteness is colour or a colour? you would reply, A colour, because there are other colours as well.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if he had said, Tell me what they are?--you would have told him of other colours which are colours just as much as whiteness.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And suppose that he were to pursue the matter in my way, he would say: Ever and anon we are landed in particulars, but this is not what I want; tell me then, since you call them by a common name, and say that they are all figures, even when opposed to one another, what is that common nature which you designate as figure--which contains straight as well as round, and is no more one than the other--that would be your mode of speaking?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in speaking thus, you do not mean to say that the round is round any more than straight, or the straight any more straight than round?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You only assert that the round figure is not more a figure than the straight, or the straight than the round?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: To what then do we give the name of figure? Try and answer. Suppose that when a person asked you this question either about figure or colour, you were to reply, Man, I do not understand what you want, or know what you are saying; he would look rather astonished and say: Do you not understand that I am looking for the 'simile in multis'? And then he might put the question in another form: Meno, he might say, what is that 'simile in multis' which you call figure, and which includes not only round and straight figures, but all? Could you not answer that question, Meno? I wish that you would try; the attempt will be good practice with a view to the answer about virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I would rather that you should answer, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Shall I indulge you?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: By all means.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And then you will tell me about virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then I must do my best, for there is a prize to be won.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, I will try and explain to you what figure is. What do you say to this answer?--Figure is the only thing which always follows colour. Will you be satisfied with it, as I am sure that I should be, if you would let me have a similar definition of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: But, Socrates, it is such a simple answer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why simple?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Because, according to you, figure is that which always follows colour. (SOCRATES: Granted.)

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: But if a person were to say that he does not know what colour is, any more than what figure is--what sort of answer would you have given him?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I should have told him the truth. And if he were a philosopher of the eristic and antagonistic sort, I should say to him: You have my answer, and if I am wrong, your business is to take up the argument and refute me. But if we were friends, and were talking as you and I are now, I should reply in a milder strain and more in the dialectician's vein; that is to say, I should not only speak the truth, but I should make use of premises which the person interrogated would be willing to admit. And this is the way in which I shall endeavour to approach you. You will acknowledge, will you not, that there is such a thing as an end, or termination, or extremity?--all which words I use in the same sense, although I am aware that Prodicus might draw distinctions about them: but still you, I am sure, would speak of a thing as ended or terminated--that is all which I am saying--not anything very difficult.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, I should; and I believe that I understand your meaning.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you would speak of a surface and also of a solid, as for example in geometry.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well then, you are now in a condition to understand my definition of figure. I define figure to be that in which the solid ends; or, more concisely, the limit of solid.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: And now, Socrates, what is colour?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You are outrageous, Meno, in thus plaguing a poor old man to give you an answer, when you will not take the trouble of remembering what is Gorgias' definition of virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: When you have told me what I ask, I will tell you, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A man who was blindfolded has only to hear you talking, and he would know that you are a fair creature and have still many lovers.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why do you think so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, because you always speak in imperatives: like all beauties when they are in their prime, you are tyrannical; and also, as I suspect, you have found out that I have weakness for the fair, and therefore to humour you I must answer.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Please do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Would you like me to answer you after the manner of Gorgias, which is familiar to you?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should like nothing better.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do not he and you and Empedocles say that there are certain effluences of existence?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And passages into which and through which the effluences pass?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And some of the effluences fit into the passages, and some of them are too small or too large?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And there is such a thing as sight?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now, as Pindar says, 'read my meaning:'--colour is an effluence of form, commensurate with sight, and palpable to sense.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That, Socrates, appears to me to be an admirable answer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, yes, because it happens to be one which you have been in the habit of hearing: and your wit will have discovered, I suspect, that you may explain in the same way the nature of sound and smell, and of many other similar phenomena.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The answer, Meno, was in the orthodox solemn vein, and therefore was more acceptable to you than the other answer about figure.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, O son of Alexidemus, I cannot help thinking that the other was the better; and I am sure that you would be of the same opinion, if you would only stay and be initiated, and were not compelled, as you said yesterday, to go away before the mysteries.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: But I will stay, Socrates, if you will give me many such answers.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well then, for my own sake as well as for yours, I will do my very best; but I am afraid that I shall not be able to give you very many as good: and now, in your turn, you are to fulfil your promise, and tell me what virtue is in the universal; and do not make a singular into a plural, as the facetious say of those who break a thing, but deliver virtue to me whole and sound, and not broken into a number of pieces: I have given you the pattern.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Well then, Socrates, virtue, as I take it, is when he, who desires the honourable, is able to provide it for himself; so the poet says, and I say too-- 'Virtue is the desire of things honourable and the power of attaining them.'

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does he who desires the honourable also desire the good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then are there some who desire the evil and others who desire the good? Do not all men, my dear sir, desire good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There are some who desire evil?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you mean that they think the evils which they desire, to be good; or do they know that they are evil and yet desire them?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Both, I think.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you really imagine, Meno, that a man knows evils to be evils and desires them notwithstanding?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And desire is of possession?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, of possession.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does he think that the evils will do good to him who possesses them, or does he know that they will do him harm?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There are some who think that the evils will do them good, and others who know that they will do them harm.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And, in your opinion, do those who think that they will do them good know that they are evils?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is it not obvious that those who are ignorant of their nature do not desire them; but they desire what they suppose to be goods although they are really evils; and if they are mistaken and suppose the evils to be goods they really desire goods?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, in that case.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, and do those who, as you say, desire evils, and think that evils are hurtful to the possessor of them, know that they will be hurt by them?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: They must know it.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And must they not suppose that those who are hurt are miserable in proportion to the hurt which is inflicted upon them?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: How can it be otherwise?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But are not the miserable ill-fated?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does any one desire to be miserable and ill-fated?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should say not, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if there is no one who desires to be miserable, there is no one, Meno, who desires evil; for what is misery but the desire and possession of evil?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That appears to be the truth, Socrates, and I admit that nobody desires evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, were you not saying just now that virtue is the desire and power of attaining good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, I did say so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if this be affirmed, then the desire of good is common to all, and one man is no better than another in that respect?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if one man is not better than another in desiring good, he must be better in the power of attaining it?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, according to your definition, virtue would appear to be the power of attaining good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I entirely approve, Socrates, of the manner in which you now view this matter.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then let us see whether what you say is true from another point of view; for very likely you may be right:--You affirm virtue to be the power of attaining goods?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the goods which you mean are such as health and wealth and the possession of gold and silver, and having office and honour in the state--those are what you would call goods?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, I should include all those.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, according to Meno, who is the hereditary friend of the great king, virtue is the power of getting silver and gold; and would you add that they must be gained piously, justly, or do you deem this to be of no consequence? And is any mode of acquisition, even if unjust and dishonest, equally to be deemed virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Not virtue, Socrates, but vice.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then justice or temperance or holiness, or some other part of virtue, as would appear, must accompany the acquisition, and without them the mere acquisition of good will not be virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why, how can there be virtue without these?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the non-acquisition of gold and silver in a dishonest manner for oneself or another, or in other words the want of them, may be equally virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the acquisition of such goods is no more virtue than the non-acquisition and want of them, but whatever is accompanied by justice or honesty is virtue, and whatever is devoid of justice is vice.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: It cannot be otherwise, in my judgment.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And were we not saying just now that justice, temperance, and the like, were each of them a part of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And so, Meno, this is the way in which you mock me.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why do you say that, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, because I asked you to deliver virtue into my hands whole and unbroken, and I gave you a pattern according to which you were to frame your answer; and you have forgotten already, and tell me that virtue is the power of attaining good justly, or with justice; and justice you acknowledge to be a part of virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then it follows from your own admissions, that virtue is doing what you do with a part of virtue; for justice and the like are said by you to be parts of virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What of that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What of that! Why, did not I ask you to tell me the nature of virtue as a whole? And you are very far from telling me this; but declare every action to be virtue which is done with a part of virtue; as though you had told me and I must already know the whole of virtue, and this too when frittered away into little pieces. And, therefore, my dear Meno, I fear that I must begin again and repeat the same question: What is virtue? for otherwise, I can only say, that every action done with a part of virtue is virtue; what else is the meaning of saying that every action done with justice is virtue? Ought I not to ask the question over again; for can any one who does not know virtue know a part of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: No; I do not say that he can.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you remember how, in the example of figure, we rejected any answer given in terms which were as yet unexplained or unadmitted?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates; and we were quite right in doing so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But then, my friend, do not suppose that we can explain to any one the nature of virtue as a whole through some unexplained portion of virtue, or anything at all in that fashion; we should only have to ask over again the old question, What is virtue? Am I not right?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I believe that you are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then begin again, and answer me, What, according to you and your friend Gorgias, is the definition of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: O Socrates, I used to be told, before I knew you, that you were always doubting yourself and making others doubt; and now you are casting your spells over me, and I am simply getting bewitched and enchanted, and am at my wits' end. And if I may venture to make a jest upon you, you seem to me both in your appearance and in your power over others to be very like the flat torpedo fish, who torpifies those who come near him and touch him, as you have now torpified me, I think. For my soul and my tongue are really torpid, and I do not know how to answer you; and though I have been delivered of an infinite variety of speeches about virtue before now, and to many persons--and very good ones they were, as I thought--at this moment I cannot even say what virtue is. And I think that you are very wise in not voyaging and going away from home, for if you did in other places as you do in Athens, you would be cast into prison as a magician.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You are a rogue, Meno, and had all but caught me.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What do you mean, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I can tell why you made a simile about me.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In order that I might make another simile about you. For I know that all pretty young gentlemen like to have pretty similes made about them--as well they may--but I shall not return the compliment. As to my being a torpedo, if the torpedo is torpid as well as the cause of torpidity in others, then indeed I am a torpedo, but not otherwise; for I perplex others, not because I am clear, but because I am utterly perplexed myself. And now I know not what virtue is, and you seem to be in the same case, although you did once perhaps know before you touched me. However, I have no objection to join with you in the enquiry.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: And how will you enquire, Socrates, into that which you do not know? What will you put forth as the subject of enquiry? And if you find what you want, how will you ever know that this is the thing which you did not know?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I know, Meno, what you mean; but just see what a tiresome dispute you are introducing. You argue that a man cannot enquire either about that which he knows, or about that which he does not know; for if he knows, he has no need to enquire; and if not, he cannot; for he does not know the very subject about which he is to enquire (Compare Aristot. Post. Anal.).

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Well, Socrates, and is not the argument sound?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will tell you why: I have heard from certain wise men and women who spoke of things divine that--

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What did they say?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: They spoke of a glorious truth, as I conceive.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What was it? and who were they?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Some of them were priests and priestesses, who had studied how they might be able to give a reason of their profession: there have been poets also, who spoke of these things by inspiration, like Pindar, and many others who were inspired. And they say--mark, now, and see whether their words are true--they say that the soul of man is immortal, and at one time has an end, which is termed dying, and at another time is born again, but is never destroyed. And the moral is, that a man ought to live always in perfect holiness. 'For in the ninth year Persephone sends the souls of those from whom she has received the penalty of ancient crime back again from beneath into the light of the sun above, and these are they who become noble kings and mighty men and great in wisdom and are called saintly heroes in after ages.' The soul, then, as being immortal, and having been born again many times, and having seen all things that exist, whether in this world or in the world below, has knowledge of them all; and it is no wonder that she should be able to call to remembrance all that she ever knew about virtue, and about everything; for as all nature is akin, and the soul has learned all things; there is no difficulty in her eliciting or as men say learning, out of a single recollection all the rest, if a man is strenuous and does not faint; for all enquiry and all learning is but recollection. And therefore we ought not to listen to this sophistical argument about the impossibility of enquiry: for it will make us idle; and is sweet only to the sluggard; but the other saying will make us active and inquisitive. In that confiding, I will gladly enquire with you into the nature of virtue.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates; but what do you mean by saying that we do not learn, and that what we call learning is only a process of recollection? Can you teach me how this is?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I told you, Meno, just now that you were a rogue, and now you ask whether I can teach you, when I am saying that there is no teaching, but only recollection; and thus you imagine that you will involve me in a contradiction.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Indeed, Socrates, I protest that I had no such intention. I only asked the question from habit; but if you can prove to me that what you say is true, I wish that you would.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: It will be no easy matter, but I will try to please you to the utmost of my power. Suppose that you call one of your numerous attendants, that I may demonstrate on him.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly. Come hither, boy.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He is Greek, and speaks Greek, does he not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, indeed; he was born in the house.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Attend now to the questions which I ask him, and observe whether he learns of me or only remembers.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Tell me, boy, do you know that a figure like this is a square?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you know that a square figure has these four lines equal?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And these lines which I have drawn through the middle of the square are also equal?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A square may be of any size?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if one side of the figure be of two feet, and the other side be of two feet, how much will the whole be? Let me explain: if in one direction the space was of two feet, and in the other direction of one foot, the whole would be of two feet taken once?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But since this side is also of two feet, there are twice two feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: There are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the square is of twice two feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how many are twice two feet? count and tell me.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Four, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And might there not be another square twice as large as this, and having like this the lines equal?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And of how many feet will that be?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Of eight feet.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now try and tell me the length of the line which forms the side of that double square: this is two feet--what will that be?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Clearly, Socrates, it will be double.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you observe, Meno, that I am not teaching the boy anything, but only asking him questions; and now he fancies that he knows how long a line is necessary in order to produce a figure of eight square feet; does he not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does he really know?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He only guesses that because the square is double, the line is double.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Observe him while he recalls the steps in regular order. (To the Boy:) Tell me, boy, do you assert that a double space comes from a double line? Remember that I am not speaking of an oblong, but of a figure equal every way, and twice the size of this--that is to say of eight feet; and I want to know whether you still say that a double square comes from double line?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But does not this line become doubled if we add another such line here?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And four such lines will make a space containing eight feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us describe such a figure: Would you not say that this is the figure of eight feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are there not these four divisions in the figure, each of which is equal to the figure of four feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not that four times four?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And four times is not double?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: No, indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But how much?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Four times as much.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Therefore the double line, boy, has given a space, not twice, but four times as much.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Four times four are sixteen--are they not?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What line would give you a space of eight feet, as this gives one of sixteen feet;--do you see?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the space of four feet is made from this half line?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Good; and is not a space of eight feet twice the size of this, and half the size of the other?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Such a space, then, will be made out of a line greater than this one, and less than that one?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes; I think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good; I like to hear you say what you think. And now tell me, is not this a line of two feet and that of four?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the line which forms the side of eight feet ought to be more than this line of two feet, and less than the other of four feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: It ought.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Try and see if you can tell me how much it will be.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Three feet.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then if we add a half to this line of two, that will be the line of three. Here are two and there is one; and on the other side, here are two also and there is one: and that makes the figure of which you speak?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if there are three feet this way and three feet that way, the whole space will be three times three feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: That is evident.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how much are three times three feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Nine.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how much is the double of four?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Eight.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the figure of eight is not made out of a line of three?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But from what line?--tell me exactly; and if you would rather not reckon, try and show me the line.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Indeed, Socrates, I do not know.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you see, Meno, what advances he has made in his power of recollection? He did not know at first, and he does not know now, what is the side of a figure of eight feet: but then he thought that he knew, and answered confidently as if he knew, and had no difficulty; now he has a difficulty, and neither knows nor fancies that he knows.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is he not better off in knowing his ignorance?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think that he is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If we have made him doubt, and given him the 'torpedo's shock,' have we done him any harm?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We have certainly, as would seem, assisted him in some degree to the discovery of the truth; and now he will wish to remedy his ignorance, but then he would have been ready to tell all the world again and again that the double space should have a double side.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But do you suppose that he would ever have enquired into or learned what he fancied that he knew, though he was really ignorant of it, until he had fallen into perplexity under the idea that he did not know, and had desired to know?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he was the better for the torpedo's touch?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Mark now the farther development. I shall only ask him, and not teach him, and he shall share the enquiry with me: and do you watch and see if you find me telling or explaining anything to him, instead of eliciting his opinion. Tell me, boy, is not this a square of four feet which I have drawn?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now I add another square equal to the former one?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And a third, which is equal to either of them?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Suppose that we fill up the vacant corner?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Here, then, there are four equal spaces?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how many times larger is this space than this other?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Four times.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But it ought to have been twice only, as you will remember.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does not this line, reaching from corner to corner, bisect each of these spaces?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are there not here four equal lines which contain this space?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: There are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Look and see how much this space is.

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: I do not understand.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Has not each interior line cut off half of the four spaces?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how many spaces are there in this section?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Four.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how many in this?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Two.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And four is how many times two?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Twice.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this space is of how many feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Of eight feet.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And from what line do you get this figure?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: From this.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That is, from the line which extends from corner to corner of the figure of four feet?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And that is the line which the learned call the diagonal. And if this is the proper name, then you, Meno's slave, are prepared to affirm that the double space is the square of the diagonal?

Speaker: BOY
Dialogue: Certainly, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What do you say of him, Meno? Were not all these answers given out of his own head?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, they were all his own.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, as we were just now saying, he did not know?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But still he had in him those notions of his--had he not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he who does not know may still have true notions of that which he does not know?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: He has.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And at present these notions have just been stirred up in him, as in a dream; but if he were frequently asked the same questions, in different forms, he would know as well as any one at last?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I dare say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Without any one teaching him he will recover his knowledge for himself, if he is only asked questions?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this spontaneous recovery of knowledge in him is recollection?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this knowledge which he now has must he not either have acquired or always possessed?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if he always possessed this knowledge he would always have known; or if he has acquired the knowledge he could not have acquired it in this life, unless he has been taught geometry; for he may be made to do the same with all geometry and every other branch of knowledge. Now, has any one ever taught him all this? You must know about him, if, as you say, he was born and bred in your house.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: And I am certain that no one ever did teach him.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet he has the knowledge?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: The fact, Socrates, is undeniable.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if he did not acquire the knowledge in this life, then he must have had and learned it at some other time?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Clearly he must.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Which must have been the time when he was not a man?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if there have been always true thoughts in him, both at the time when he was and was not a man, which only need to be awakened into knowledge by putting questions to him, his soul must have always possessed this knowledge, for he always either was or was not a man?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Obviously.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if the truth of all things always existed in the soul, then the soul is immortal. Wherefore be of good cheer, and try to recollect what you do not know, or rather what you do not remember.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I feel, somehow, that I like what you are saying.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And I, Meno, like what I am saying. Some things I have said of which I am not altogether confident. But that we shall be better and braver and less helpless if we think that we ought to enquire, than we should have been if we indulged in the idle fancy that there was no knowing and no use in seeking to know what we do not know;--that is a theme upon which I am ready to fight, in word and deed, to the utmost of my power.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There again, Socrates, your words seem to me excellent.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, as we are agreed that a man should enquire about that which he does not know, shall you and I make an effort to enquire together into the nature of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: By all means, Socrates. And yet I would much rather return to my original question, Whether in seeking to acquire virtue we should regard it as a thing to be taught, or as a gift of nature, or as coming to men in some other way?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Had I the command of you as well as of myself, Meno, I would not have enquired whether virtue is given by instruction or not, until we had first ascertained 'what it is.' But as you think only of controlling me who am your slave, and never of controlling yourself,--such being your notion of freedom, I must yield to you, for you are irresistible. And therefore I have now to enquire into the qualities of a thing of which I do not as yet know the nature. At any rate, will you condescend a little, and allow the question 'Whether virtue is given by instruction, or in any other way,' to be argued upon hypothesis? As the geometrician, when he is asked whether a certain triangle is capable being inscribed in a certain circle (Or, whether a certain area is capable of being inscribed as a triangle in a certain circle.), will reply: 'I cannot tell you as yet; but I will offer a hypothesis which may assist us in forming a conclusion: If the figure be such that when you have produced a given side of it (Or, when you apply it to the given line, i.e. the diameter of the circle (autou).), the given area of the triangle falls short by an area corresponding to the part produced (Or, similar to the area so applied.), then one consequence follows, and if this is impossible then some other; and therefore I wish to assume a hypothesis before I tell you whether this triangle is capable of being inscribed in the circle':--that is a geometrical hypothesis. And we too, as we know not the nature and qualities of virtue, must ask, whether virtue is or is not taught, under a hypothesis: as thus, if virtue is of such a class of mental goods, will it be taught or not? Let the first hypothesis be that virtue is or is not knowledge,--in that case will it be taught or not? or, as we were just now saying, 'remembered'? For there is no use in disputing about the name. But is virtue taught or not? or rather, does not every one see that knowledge alone is taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then if virtue is knowledge, virtue will be taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now we have made a quick end of this question: if virtue is of such a nature, it will be taught; and if not, not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The next question is, whether virtue is knowledge or of another species?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, that appears to be the question which comes next in order.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do we not say that virtue is a good?--This is a hypothesis which is not set aside.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Now, if there be any sort of good which is distinct from knowledge, virtue may be that good; but if knowledge embraces all good, then we shall be right in thinking that virtue is knowledge?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And virtue makes us good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if we are good, then we are profitable; for all good things are profitable?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then virtue is profitable?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That is the only inference.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now let us see what are the things which severally profit us. Health and strength, and beauty and wealth--these, and the like of these, we call profitable?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet these things may also sometimes do us harm: would you not think so?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what is the guiding principle which makes them profitable or the reverse? Are they not profitable when they are rightly used, and hurtful when they are not rightly used?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Next, let us consider the goods of the soul: they are temperance, justice, courage, quickness of apprehension, memory, magnanimity, and the like?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Surely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And such of these as are not knowledge, but of another sort, are sometimes profitable and sometimes hurtful; as, for example, courage wanting prudence, which is only a sort of confidence? When a man has no sense he is harmed by courage, but when he has sense he is profited?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the same may be said of temperance and quickness of apprehension; whatever things are learned or done with sense are profitable, but when done without sense they are hurtful?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in general, all that the soul attempts or endures, when under the guidance of wisdom, ends in happiness; but when she is under the guidance of folly, in the opposite?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That appears to be true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If then virtue is a quality of the soul, and is admitted to be profitable, it must be wisdom or prudence, since none of the things of the soul are either profitable or hurtful in themselves, but they are all made profitable or hurtful by the addition of wisdom or of folly; and therefore if virtue is profitable, virtue must be a sort of wisdom or prudence?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I quite agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the other goods, such as wealth and the like, of which we were just now saying that they are sometimes good and sometimes evil, do not they also become profitable or hurtful, accordingly as the soul guides and uses them rightly or wrongly; just as the things of the soul herself are benefited when under the guidance of wisdom and harmed by folly?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the wise soul guides them rightly, and the foolish soul wrongly.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not this universally true of human nature? All other things hang upon the soul, and the things of the soul herself hang upon wisdom, if they are to be good; and so wisdom is inferred to be that which profits--and virtue, as we say, is profitable?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And thus we arrive at the conclusion that virtue is either wholly or partly wisdom?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think that what you are saying, Socrates, is very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if this is true, then the good are not by nature good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If they had been, there would assuredly have been discerners of characters among us who would have known our future great men; and on their showing we should have adopted them, and when we had got them, we should have kept them in the citadel out of the way of harm, and set a stamp upon them far rather than upon a piece of gold, in order that no one might tamper with them; and when they grew up they would have been useful to the state?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates, that would have been the right way.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if the good are not by nature good, are they made good by instruction?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There appears to be no other alternative, Socrates. On the supposition that virtue is knowledge, there can be no doubt that virtue is taught.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, indeed; but what if the supposition is erroneous?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I certainly thought just now that we were right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, Meno; but a principle which has any soundness should stand firm not only just now, but always.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Well; and why are you so slow of heart to believe that knowledge is virtue?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will try and tell you why, Meno. I do not retract the assertion that if virtue is knowledge it may be taught; but I fear that I have some reason in doubting whether virtue is knowledge: for consider now and say whether virtue, and not only virtue but anything that is taught, must not have teachers and disciples?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Surely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And conversely, may not the art of which neither teachers nor disciples exist be assumed to be incapable of being taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True; but do you think that there are no teachers of virtue?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have certainly often enquired whether there were any, and taken great pains to find them, and have never succeeded; and many have assisted me in the search, and they were the persons whom I thought the most likely to know. Here at the moment when he is wanted we fortunately have sitting by us Anytus, the very person of whom we should make enquiry; to him then let us repair. In the first place, he is the son of a wealthy and wise father, Anthemion, who acquired his wealth, not by accident or gift, like Ismenias the Theban (who has recently made himself as rich as Polycrates), but by his own skill and industry, and who is a well-conditioned, modest man, not insolent, or overbearing, or annoying; moreover, this son of his has received a good education, as the Athenian people certainly appear to think, for they choose him to fill the highest offices. And these are the sort of men from whom you are likely to learn whether there are any teachers of virtue, and who they are. Please, Anytus, to help me and your friend Meno in answering our question, Who are the teachers? Consider the matter thus: If we wanted Meno to be a good physician, to whom should we send him? Should we not send him to the physicians?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or if we wanted him to be a good cobbler, should we not send him to the cobblers?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And so forth?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let me trouble you with one more question. When we say that we should be right in sending him to the physicians if we wanted him to be a physician, do we mean that we should be right in sending him to those who profess the art, rather than to those who do not, and to those who demand payment for teaching the art, and profess to teach it to any one who will come and learn? And if these were our reasons, should we not be right in sending him?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And might not the same be said of flute-playing, and of the other arts? Would a man who wanted to make another a flute-player refuse to send him to those who profess to teach the art for money, and be plaguing other persons to give him instruction, who are not professed teachers and who never had a single disciple in that branch of knowledge which he wishes him to acquire--would not such conduct be the height of folly?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Yes, by Zeus, and of ignorance too.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good. And now you are in a position to advise with me about my friend Meno. He has been telling me, Anytus, that he desires to attain that kind of wisdom and virtue by which men order the state or the house, and honour their parents, and know when to receive and when to send away citizens and strangers, as a good man should. Now, to whom should he go in order that he may learn this virtue? Does not the previous argument imply clearly that we should send him to those who profess and avouch that they are the common teachers of all Hellas, and are ready to impart instruction to any one who likes, at a fixed price?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Whom do you mean, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You surely know, do you not, Anytus, that these are the people whom mankind call Sophists?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: By Heracles, Socrates, forbear! I only hope that no friend or kinsman or acquaintance of mine, whether citizen or stranger, will ever be so mad as to allow himself to be corrupted by them; for they are a manifest pest and corrupting influence to those who have to do with them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What, Anytus? Of all the people who profess that they know how to do men good, do you mean to say that these are the only ones who not only do them no good, but positively corrupt those who are entrusted to them, and in return for this disservice have the face to demand money? Indeed, I cannot believe you; for I know of a single man, Protagoras, who made more out of his craft than the illustrious Pheidias, who created such noble works, or any ten other statuaries. How could that be? A mender of old shoes, or patcher up of clothes, who made the shoes or clothes worse than he received them, could not have remained thirty days undetected, and would very soon have starved; whereas during more than forty years, Protagoras was corrupting all Hellas, and sending his disciples from him worse than he received them, and he was never found out. For, if I am not mistaken, he was about seventy years old at his death, forty of which were spent in the practice of his profession; and during all that time he had a good reputation, which to this day he retains: and not only Protagoras, but many others are well spoken of; some who lived before him, and others who are still living. Now, when you say that they deceived and corrupted the youth, are they to be supposed to have corrupted them consciously or unconsciously? Can those who were deemed by many to be the wisest men of Hellas have been out of their minds?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Out of their minds! No, Socrates; the young men who gave their money to them were out of their minds, and their relations and guardians who entrusted their youth to the care of these men were still more out of their minds, and most of all, the cities who allowed them to come in, and did not drive them out, citizen and stranger alike.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Has any of the Sophists wronged you, Anytus? What makes you so angry with them?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: No, indeed, neither I nor any of my belongings has ever had, nor would I suffer them to have, anything to do with them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you are entirely unacquainted with them?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: And I have no wish to be acquainted.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, my dear friend, how can you know whether a thing is good or bad of which you are wholly ignorant?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Quite well; I am sure that I know what manner of men these are, whether I am acquainted with them or not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You must be a diviner, Anytus, for I really cannot make out, judging from your own words, how, if you are not acquainted with them, you know about them. But I am not enquiring of you who are the teachers who will corrupt Meno (let them be, if you please, the Sophists); I only ask you to tell him who there is in this great city who will teach him how to become eminent in the virtues which I was just now describing. He is the friend of your family, and you will oblige him.

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Why do you not tell him yourself?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have told him whom I supposed to be the teachers of these things; but I learn from you that I am utterly at fault, and I dare say that you are right. And now I wish that you, on your part, would tell me to whom among the Athenians he should go. Whom would you name?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Why single out individuals? Any Athenian gentleman, taken at random, if he will mind him, will do far more good to him than the Sophists.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And did those gentlemen grow of themselves; and without having been taught by any one, were they nevertheless able to teach others that which they had never learned themselves?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: I imagine that they learned of the previous generation of gentlemen. Have there not been many good men in this city?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, certainly, Anytus; and many good statesmen also there always have been and there are still, in the city of Athens. But the question is whether they were also good teachers of their own virtue;--not whether there are, or have been, good men in this part of the world, but whether virtue can be taught, is the question which we have been discussing. Now, do we mean to say that the good men of our own and of other times knew how to impart to others that virtue which they had themselves; or is virtue a thing incapable of being communicated or imparted by one man to another? That is the question which I and Meno have been arguing. Look at the matter in your own way: Would you not admit that Themistocles was a good man?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Certainly; no man better.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And must not he then have been a good teacher, if any man ever was a good teacher, of his own virtue?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Yes certainly,--if he wanted to be so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But would he not have wanted? He would, at any rate, have desired to make his own son a good man and a gentleman; he could not have been jealous of him, or have intentionally abstained from imparting to him his own virtue. Did you never hear that he made his son Cleophantus a famous horseman; and had him taught to stand upright on horseback and hurl a javelin, and to do many other marvellous things; and in anything which could be learned from a master he was well trained? Have you not heard from our elders of him?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: I have.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then no one could say that his son showed any want of capacity?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Very likely not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But did any one, old or young, ever say in your hearing that Cleophantus, son of Themistocles, was a wise or good man, as his father was?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: I have certainly never heard any one say so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if virtue could have been taught, would his father Themistocles have sought to train him in these minor accomplishments, and allowed him who, as you must remember, was his own son, to be no better than his neighbours in those qualities in which he himself excelled?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Indeed, indeed, I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Here was a teacher of virtue whom you admit to be among the best men of the past. Let us take another,--Aristides, the son of Lysimachus: would you not acknowledge that he was a good man?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: To be sure I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And did not he train his son Lysimachus better than any other Athenian in all that could be done for him by the help of masters? But what has been the result? Is he a bit better than any other mortal? He is an acquaintance of yours, and you see what he is like. There is Pericles, again, magnificent in his wisdom; and he, as you are aware, had two sons, Paralus and Xanthippus.

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you know, also, that he taught them to be unrivalled horsemen, and had them trained in music and gymnastics and all sorts of arts--in these respects they were on a level with the best--and had he no wish to make good men of them? Nay, he must have wished it. But virtue, as I suspect, could not be taught. And that you may not suppose the incompetent teachers to be only the meaner sort of Athenians and few in number, remember again that Thucydides had two sons, Melesias and Stephanus, whom, besides giving them a good education in other things, he trained in wrestling, and they were the best wrestlers in Athens: one of them he committed to the care of Xanthias, and the other of Eudorus, who had the reputation of being the most celebrated wrestlers of that day. Do you remember them?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: I have heard of them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Now, can there be a doubt that Thucydides, whose children were taught things for which he had to spend money, would have taught them to be good men, which would have cost him nothing, if virtue could have been taught? Will you reply that he was a mean man, and had not many friends among the Athenians and allies? Nay, but he was of a great family, and a man of influence at Athens and in all Hellas, and, if virtue could have been taught, he would have found out some Athenian or foreigner who would have made good men of his sons, if he could not himself spare the time from cares of state. Once more, I suspect, friend Anytus, that virtue is not a thing which can be taught?

Speaker: ANYTUS
Dialogue: Socrates, I think that you are too ready to speak evil of men: and, if you will take my advice, I would recommend you to be careful. Perhaps there is no city in which it is not easier to do men harm than to do them good, and this is certainly the case at Athens, as I believe that you know.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: O Meno, think that Anytus is in a rage. And he may well be in a rage, for he thinks, in the first place, that I am defaming these gentlemen; and in the second place, he is of opinion that he is one of them himself. But some day he will know what is the meaning of defamation, and if he ever does, he will forgive me. Meanwhile I will return to you, Meno; for I suppose that there are gentlemen in your region too?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly there are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are they willing to teach the young? and do they profess to be teachers? and do they agree that virtue is taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: No indeed, Socrates, they are anything but agreed; you may hear them saying at one time that virtue can be taught, and then again the reverse.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Can we call those teachers who do not acknowledge the possibility of their own vocation?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what do you think of these Sophists, who are the only professors? Do they seem to you to be teachers of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I often wonder, Socrates, that Gorgias is never heard promising to teach virtue: and when he hears others promising he only laughs at them; but he thinks that men should be taught to speak.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then do you not think that the Sophists are teachers?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I cannot tell you, Socrates; like the rest of the world, I am in doubt, and sometimes I think that they are teachers and sometimes not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are you aware that not you only and other politicians have doubts whether virtue can be taught or not, but that Theognis the poet says the very same thing?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Where does he say so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In these elegiac verses (Theog.): 'Eat and drink and sit with the mighty, and make yourself agreeable to them; for from the good you will learn what is good, but if you mix with the bad you will lose the intelligence which you already have.' Do you observe that here he seems to imply that virtue can be taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But in some other verses he shifts about and says (Theog.): 'If understanding could be created and put into a man, then they' (who were able to perform this feat) 'would have obtained great rewards.' And again:-- 'Never would a bad son have sprung from a good sire, for he would have heard the voice of instruction; but not by teaching will you ever make a bad man into a good one.' And this, as you may remark, is a contradiction of the other.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is there anything else of which the professors are affirmed not only not to be teachers of others, but to be ignorant themselves, and bad at the knowledge of that which they are professing to teach? or is there anything about which even the acknowledged 'gentlemen' are sometimes saying that 'this thing can be taught,' and sometimes the opposite? Can you say that they are teachers in any true sense whose ideas are in such confusion?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I should say, certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if neither the Sophists nor the gentlemen are teachers, clearly there can be no other teachers?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if there are no teachers, neither are there disciples?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And we have admitted that a thing cannot be taught of which there are neither teachers nor disciples?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: We have.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And there are no teachers of virtue to be found anywhere?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There are not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if there are no teachers, neither are there scholars?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That, I think, is true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then virtue cannot be taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Not if we are right in our view. But I cannot believe, Socrates, that there are no good men: And if there are, how did they come into existence?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am afraid, Meno, that you and I are not good for much, and that Gorgias has been as poor an educator of you as Prodicus has been of me. Certainly we shall have to look to ourselves, and try to find some one who will help in some way or other to improve us. This I say, because I observe that in the previous discussion none of us remarked that right and good action is possible to man under other guidance than that of knowledge (episteme);--and indeed if this be denied, there is no seeing how there can be any good men at all.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: How do you mean, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean that good men are necessarily useful or profitable. Were we not right in admitting this? It must be so.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in supposing that they will be useful only if they are true guides to us of action--there we were also right?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But when we said that a man cannot be a good guide unless he have knowledge (phrhonesis), this we were wrong.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What do you mean by the word 'right'?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will explain. If a man knew the way to Larisa, or anywhere else, and went to the place and led others thither, would he not be a right and good guide?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And a person who had a right opinion about the way, but had never been and did not know, might be a good guide also, might he not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And while he has true opinion about that which the other knows, he will be just as good a guide if he thinks the truth, as he who knows the truth?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then true opinion is as good a guide to correct action as knowledge; and that was the point which we omitted in our speculation about the nature of virtue, when we said that knowledge only is the guide of right action; whereas there is also right opinion.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then right opinion is not less useful than knowledge?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: The difference, Socrates, is only that he who has knowledge will always be right; but he who has right opinion will sometimes be right, and sometimes not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What do you mean? Can he be wrong who has right opinion, so long as he has right opinion?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I admit the cogency of your argument, and therefore, Socrates, I wonder that knowledge should be preferred to right opinion--or why they should ever differ.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And shall I explain this wonder to you?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Do tell me.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You would not wonder if you had ever observed the images of Daedalus (Compare Euthyphro); but perhaps you have not got them in your country?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What have they to do with the question?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Because they require to be fastened in order to keep them, and if they are not fastened they will play truant and run away.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Well, what of that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean to say that they are not very valuable possessions if they are at liberty, for they will walk off like runaway slaves; but when fastened, they are of great value, for they are really beautiful works of art. Now this is an illustration of the nature of true opinions: while they abide with us they are beautiful and fruitful, but they run away out of the human soul, and do not remain long, and therefore they are not of much value until they are fastened by the tie of the cause; and this fastening of them, friend Meno, is recollection, as you and I have agreed to call it. But when they are bound, in the first place, they have the nature of knowledge; and, in the second place, they are abiding. And this is why knowledge is more honourable and excellent than true opinion, because fastened by a chain.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: What you are saying, Socrates, seems to be very like the truth.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I too speak rather in ignorance; I only conjecture. And yet that knowledge differs from true opinion is no matter of conjecture with me. There are not many things which I profess to know, but this is most certainly one of them.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates; and you are quite right in saying so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And am I not also right in saying that true opinion leading the way perfects action quite as well as knowledge?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: There again, Socrates, I think you are right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then right opinion is not a whit inferior to knowledge, or less useful in action; nor is the man who has right opinion inferior to him who has knowledge?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And surely the good man has been acknowledged by us to be useful?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Seeing then that men become good and useful to states, not only because they have knowledge, but because they have right opinion, and that neither knowledge nor right opinion is given to man by nature or acquired by him--(do you imagine either of them to be given by nature?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Not I.)

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then if they are not given by nature, neither are the good by nature good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And nature being excluded, then came the question whether virtue is acquired by teaching?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If virtue was wisdom (or knowledge), then, as we thought, it was taught?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if it was taught it was wisdom?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if there were teachers, it might be taught; and if there were no teachers, not?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But surely we acknowledged that there were no teachers of virtue?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then we acknowledged that it was not taught, and was not wisdom?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet we admitted that it was a good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the right guide is useful and good?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the only right guides are knowledge and true opinion--these are the guides of man; for things which happen by chance are not under the guidance of man: but the guides of man are true opinion and knowledge.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think so too.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if virtue is not taught, neither is virtue knowledge.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then of two good and useful things, one, which is knowledge, has been set aside, and cannot be supposed to be our guide in political life.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And therefore not by any wisdom, and not because they were wise, did Themistocles and those others of whom Anytus spoke govern states. This was the reason why they were unable to make others like themselves--because their virtue was not grounded on knowledge.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That is probably true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if not by knowledge, the only alternative which remains is that statesmen must have guided states by right opinion, which is in politics what divination is in religion; for diviners and also prophets say many things truly, but they know not what they say.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: So I believe.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And may we not, Meno, truly call those men 'divine' who, having no understanding, yet succeed in many a grand deed and word?

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then we shall also be right in calling divine those whom we were just now speaking of as diviners and prophets, including the whole tribe of poets. Yes, and statesmen above all may be said to be divine and illumined, being inspired and possessed of God, in which condition they say many grand things, not knowing what they say.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the women too, Meno, call good men divine--do they not? and the Spartans, when they praise a good man, say 'that he is a divine man.'

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: And I think, Socrates, that they are right; although very likely our friend Anytus may take offence at the word.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I do not care; as for Anytus, there will be another opportunity of talking with him. To sum up our enquiry--the result seems to be, if we are at all right in our view, that virtue is neither natural nor acquired, but an instinct given by God to the virtuous. Nor is the instinct accompanied by reason, unless there may be supposed to be among statesmen some one who is capable of educating statesmen. And if there be such an one, he may be said to be among the living what Homer says that Tiresias was among the dead, 'he alone has understanding; but the rest are flitting shades'; and he and his virtue in like manner will be a reality among shadows.

Speaker: MENO
Dialogue: That is excellent, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, Meno, the conclusion is that virtue comes to the virtuous by the gift of God. But we shall never know the certain truth until, before asking how virtue is given, we enquire into the actual nature of virtue. I fear that I must go away, but do you, now that you are persuaded yourself, persuade our friend Anytus. And do not let him be so exasperated; if you can conciliate him, you will have done good service to the Athenian people. *** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK MENO *** Updated editions will replace the previous one—the old editions will be renamed. Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I dare say that you may be surprised to find, O son of Cleinias, that I, who am your first lover, not having spoken to you for many years, when the rest of the world were wearying you with their attentions, am the last of your lovers who still speaks to you. The cause of my silence has been that I was hindered by a power more than human, of which I will some day explain to you the nature; this impediment has now been removed; I therefore here present myself before you, and I greatly hope that no similar hindrance will again occur.
