Meanwhile, I have observed that your pride has been too much for the pride of your admirers; they were numerous and high-spirited, but they have all run away, overpowered by your superior force of character; not one of them remains. And I want you to understand the reason why you have been too much for them. You think that you have no need of them or of any other man, for you have great possessions and lack nothing, beginning with the body, and ending with the soul. In the first place, you say to yourself that you are the fairest and tallest of the citizens, and this every one who has eyes may see to be true; in the second place, that you are among the noblest of them, highly connected both on the father's and the mother's side, and sprung from one of the most distinguished families in your own state, which is the greatest in Hellas, and having many friends and kinsmen of the best sort, who can assist you when in need; and there is one potent relative, who is more to you than all the rest, Pericles the son of Xanthippus, whom your father left guardian of you, and of your brother, and who can do as he pleases not only in this city, but in all Hellas, and among many and mighty barbarous nations. Moreover, you are rich; but I must say that you value yourself least of all upon your possessions. And all these things have lifted you up; you have overcome your lovers, and they have acknowledged that you were too much for them. Have you not remarked their absence? And now I know that you wonder why I, unlike the rest of them, have not gone away, and what can be my motive in remaining.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Perhaps, Socrates, you are not aware that I was just going to ask you the very same question--What do you want? And what is your motive in annoying me, and always, wherever I am, making a point of coming? (Compare Symp.) I do really wonder what you mean, and should greatly like to know.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then if, as you say, you desire to know, I suppose that you will be willing to hear, and I may consider myself to be speaking to an auditor who will remain, and will not run away?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly, let me hear.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You had better be careful, for I may very likely be as unwilling to end as I have hitherto been to begin.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Proceed, my good man, and I will listen.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will proceed; and, although no lover likes to speak with one who has no feeling of love in him (compare Symp.), I will make an effort, and tell you what I meant: My love, Alcibiades, which I hardly like to confess, would long ago have passed away, as I flatter myself, if I saw you loving your good things, or thinking that you ought to pass life in the enjoyment of them. But I shall reveal other thoughts of yours, which you keep to yourself; whereby you will know that I have always had my eye on you. Suppose that at this moment some God came to you and said: Alcibiades, will you live as you are, or die in an instant if you are forbidden to make any further acquisition?--I verily believe that you would choose death. And I will tell you the hope in which you are at present living: Before many days have elapsed, you think that you will come before the Athenian assembly, and will prove to them that you are more worthy of honour than Pericles, or any other man that ever lived, and having proved this, you will have the greatest power in the state. When you have gained the greatest power among us, you will go on to other Hellenic states, and not only to Hellenes, but to all the barbarians who inhabit the same continent with us. And if the God were then to say to you again: Here in Europe is to be your seat of empire, and you must not cross over into Asia or meddle with Asiatic affairs, I do not believe that you would choose to live upon these terms; but the world, as I may say, must be filled with your power and name--no man less than Cyrus and Xerxes is of any account with you. Such I know to be your hopes--I am not guessing only--and very likely you, who know that I am speaking the truth, will reply, Well, Socrates, but what have my hopes to do with the explanation which you promised of your unwillingness to leave me? And that is what I am now going to tell you, sweet son of Cleinias and Dinomache. The explanation is, that all these designs of yours cannot be accomplished by you without my help; so great is the power which I believe myself to have over you and your concerns; and this I conceive to be the reason why the God has hitherto forbidden me to converse with you, and I have been long expecting his permission. For, as you hope to prove your own great value to the state, and having proved it, to attain at once to absolute power, so do I indulge a hope that I shall be the supreme power over you, if I am able to prove my own great value to you, and to show you that neither guardian, nor kinsman, nor any one is able to deliver into your hands the power which you desire, but I only, God being my helper. When you were young (compare Symp.) and your hopes were not yet matured, I should have wasted my time, and therefore, as I conceive, the God forbade me to converse with you; but now, having his permission, I will speak, for now you will listen to me.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Your silence, Socrates, was always a surprise to me. I never could understand why you followed me about, and now that you have begun to speak again, I am still more amazed. Whether I think all this or not, is a matter about which you seem to have already made up your mind, and therefore my denial will have no effect upon you. But granting, if I must, that you have perfectly divined my purposes, why is your assistance necessary to the attainment of them? Can you tell me why?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You want to know whether I can make a long speech, such as you are in the habit of hearing; but that is not my way. I think, however, that I can prove to you the truth of what I am saying, if you will grant me one little favour.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, if the favour which you mean be not a troublesome one.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Will you be troubled at having questions to answer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then please to answer.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Ask me.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Have you not the intention which I attribute to you?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I will grant anything you like, in the hope of hearing what more you have to say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You do, then, mean, as I was saying, to come forward in a little while in the character of an adviser of the Athenians? And suppose that when you are ascending the bema, I pull you by the sleeve and say, Alcibiades, you are getting up to advise the Athenians--do you know the matter about which they are going to deliberate, better than they?--How would you answer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should reply, that I was going to advise them about a matter which I do know better than they.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you are a good adviser about the things which you know?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you know anything but what you have learned of others, or found out yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That is all.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And would you have ever learned or discovered anything, if you had not been willing either to learn of others or to examine yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And would you have been willing to learn or to examine what you supposed that you knew?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then there was a time when you thought that you did not know what you are now supposed to know?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I think that I know tolerably well the extent of your acquirements; and you must tell me if I forget any of them: according to my recollection, you learned the arts of writing, of playing on the lyre, and of wrestling; the flute you never would learn; this is the sum of your accomplishments, unless there were some which you acquired in secret; and I think that secrecy was hardly possible, as you could not have come out of your door, either by day or night, without my seeing you.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, that was the whole of my schooling.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are you going to get up in the Athenian assembly, and give them advice about writing?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No, indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or about the touch of the lyre?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they are not in the habit of deliberating about wrestling, in the assembly?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Hardly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what are the deliberations in which you propose to advise them? Surely not about building?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: For the builder will advise better than you will about that?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: He will.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor about divination?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: About that again the diviner will advise better than you will?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whether he be little or great, good or ill-looking, noble or ignoble--makes no difference.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A man is a good adviser about anything, not because he has riches, but because he has knowledge?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Assuredly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whether their counsellor is rich or poor, is not a matter which will make any difference to the Athenians when they are deliberating about the health of the citizens; they only require that he should be a physician.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what will be the subject of deliberation about which you will be justified in getting up and advising them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: About their own concerns, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean about shipbuilding, for example, when the question is what sort of ships they ought to build?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No, I should not advise them about that.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I suppose, because you do not understand shipbuilding:--is that the reason?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then about what concerns of theirs will you advise them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: About war, Socrates, or about peace, or about any other concerns of the state.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean, when they deliberate with whom they ought to make peace, and with whom they ought to go to war, and in what manner?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they ought to go to war with those against whom it is better to go to war?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when it is better?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And for as long a time as is better?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But suppose the Athenians to deliberate with whom they ought to close in wrestling, and whom they should grasp by the hand, would you, or the master of gymnastics, be a better adviser of them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly, the master of gymnastics.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can you tell me on what grounds the master of gymnastics would decide, with whom they ought or ought not to close, and when and how? To take an instance: Would he not say that they should wrestle with those against whom it is best to wrestle?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And as much as is best?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And at such times as are best?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Again; you sometimes accompany the lyre with the song and dance?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When it is well to do so?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And as much as is well?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Just so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And as you speak of an excellence or art of the best in wrestling, and of an excellence in playing the lyre, I wish you would tell me what this latter is;--the excellence of wrestling I call gymnastic, and I want to know what you call the other.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do not understand you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then try to do as I do; for the answer which I gave is universally right, and when I say right, I mean according to rule.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And was not the art of which I spoke gymnastic?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And I called the excellence in wrestling gymnastic?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And I was right?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I think that you were.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, now,--for you should learn to argue prettily--let me ask you in return to tell me, first, what is that art of which playing and singing, and stepping properly in the dance, are parts,--what is the name of the whole? I think that by this time you must be able to tell.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Indeed I cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then let me put the matter in another way: what do you call the Goddesses who are the patronesses of art?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The Muses do you mean, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, I do; and what is the name of the art which is called after them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose that you mean music.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, that is my meaning; and what is the excellence of the art of music, as I told you truly that the excellence of wrestling was gymnastic--what is the excellence of music--to be what?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: To be musical, I suppose.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good; and now please to tell me what is the excellence of war and peace; as the more musical was the more excellent, or the more gymnastical was the more excellent, tell me, what name do you give to the more excellent in war and peace?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But I really cannot tell you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if you were offering advice to another and said to him--This food is better than that, at this time and in this quantity, and he said to you--What do you mean, Alcibiades, by the word 'better'? you would have no difficulty in replying that you meant 'more wholesome,' although you do not profess to be a physician: and when the subject is one of which you profess to have knowledge, and about which you are ready to get up and advise as if you knew, are you not ashamed, when you are asked, not to be able to answer the question? Is it not disgraceful?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, consider and try to explain what is the meaning of 'better,' in the matter of making peace and going to war with those against whom you ought to go to war? To what does the word refer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I am thinking, and I cannot tell.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But you surely know what are the charges which we bring against one another, when we arrive at the point of making war, and what name we give them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, certainly; we say that deceit or violence has been employed, or that we have been defrauded.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how does this happen? Will you tell me how? For there may be a difference in the manner.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Do you mean by 'how,' Socrates, whether we suffered these things justly or unjustly?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: There can be no greater difference than between just and unjust.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And would you advise the Athenians to go to war with the just or with the unjust?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That is an awkward question; for certainly, even if a person did intend to go to war with the just, he would not admit that they were just.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He would not go to war, because it would be unlawful?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Neither lawful nor honourable.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you, too, would address them on principles of justice?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What, then, is justice but that better, of which I spoke, in going to war or not going to war with those against whom we ought or ought not, and when we ought or ought not to go to war?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But how is this, friend Alcibiades? Have you forgotten that you do not know this, or have you been to the schoolmaster without my knowledge, and has he taught you to discern the just from the unjust? Who is he? I wish you would tell me, that I may go and learn of him--you shall introduce me.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You are mocking, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No, indeed; I most solemnly declare to you by Zeus, who is the God of our common friendship, and whom I never will forswear, that I am not; tell me, then, who this instructor is, if he exists.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But, perhaps, he does not exist; may I not have acquired the knowledge of just and unjust in some other way?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes; if you have discovered them.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But do you not think that I could discover them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am sure that you might, if you enquired about them.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: And do you not think that I would enquire?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes; if you thought that you did not know them.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: And was there not a time when I did so think?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good; and can you tell me how long it is since you thought that you did not know the nature of the just and the unjust? What do you say to a year ago? Were you then in a state of conscious ignorance and enquiry? Or did you think that you knew? And please to answer truly, that our discussion may not be in vain.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Well, I thought that I knew.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And two years ago, and three years ago, and four years ago, you knew all the same?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And more than four years ago you were a child--were you not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And then I am quite sure that you thought you knew.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why are you so sure?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Because I often heard you when a child, in your teacher's house, or elsewhere, playing at dice or some other game with the boys, not hesitating at all about the nature of the just and unjust; but very confident--crying and shouting that one of the boys was a rogue and a cheat, and had been cheating. Is it not true?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But what was I to do, Socrates, when anybody cheated me?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how can you say, 'What was I to do'? if at the time you did not know whether you were wronged or not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: To be sure I knew; I was quite aware that I was being cheated.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you suppose yourself even when a child to have known the nature of just and unjust?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly; and I did know then.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when did you discover them--not, surely, at the time when you thought that you knew them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when did you think that you were ignorant--if you consider, you will find that there never was such a time?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Really, Socrates, I cannot say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you did not learn them by discovering them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But just before you said that you did not know them by learning; now, if you have neither discovered nor learned them, how and whence do you come to know them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose that I was mistaken in saying that I knew them through my own discovery of them; whereas, in truth, I learned them in the same way that other people learn.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: So you said before, and I must again ask, of whom? Do tell me.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Of the many.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you take refuge in them? I cannot say much for your teachers.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, are they not able to teach?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: They could not teach you how to play at draughts, which you would acknowledge (would you not) to be a much smaller matter than justice?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can they teach the better who are unable to teach the worse?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I think that they can; at any rate, they can teach many far better things than to play at draughts.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What things?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, for example, I learned to speak Greek of them, and I cannot say who was my teacher, or to whom I am to attribute my knowledge of Greek, if not to those good-for-nothing teachers, as you call them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, yes, my friend; and the many are good enough teachers of Greek, and some of their instructions in that line may be justly praised.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, because they have the qualities which good teachers ought to have.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What qualities?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, you know that knowledge is the first qualification of any teacher?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if they know, they must agree together and not differ?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And would you say that they knew the things about which they differ?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then how can they teach them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: They cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but do you imagine that the many would differ about the nature of wood and stone? are they not agreed if you ask them what they are? and do they not run to fetch the same thing, when they want a piece of wood or a stone? And so in similar cases, which I suspect to be pretty nearly all that you mean by speaking Greek.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: These, as we were saying, are matters about which they are agreed with one another and with themselves; both individuals and states use the same words about them; they do not use some one word and some another.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: They do not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then they may be expected to be good teachers of these things?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if we want to instruct any one in them, we shall be right in sending him to be taught by our friends the many?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if we wanted further to know not only which are men and which are horses, but which men or horses have powers of running, would the many still be able to inform us?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you have a sufficient proof that they do not know these things and are not the best teachers of them, inasmuch as they are never agreed about them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And suppose that we wanted to know not only what men are like, but what healthy or diseased men are like--would the many be able to teach us?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: They would not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you would have a proof that they were bad teachers of these matters, if you saw them at variance?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but are the many agreed with themselves, or with one another, about the justice or injustice of men and things?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Assuredly not, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is no subject about which they are more at variance?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: None.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I do not suppose that you ever saw or heard of men quarrelling over the principles of health and disease to such an extent as to go to war and kill one another for the sake of them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But of the quarrels about justice and injustice, even if you have never seen them, you have certainly heard from many people, including Homer; for you have heard of the Iliad and Odyssey?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: To be sure, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A difference of just and unjust is the argument of those poems?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Which difference caused all the wars and deaths of Trojans and Achaeans, and the deaths of the suitors of Penelope in their quarrel with Odysseus.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when the Athenians and Lacedaemonians and Boeotians fell at Tanagra, and afterwards in the battle of Coronea, at which your father Cleinias met his end, the question was one of justice--this was the sole cause of the battles, and of their deaths.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But can they be said to understand that about which they are quarrelling to the death?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet those whom you thus allow to be ignorant are the teachers to whom you are appealing.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But how are you ever likely to know the nature of justice and injustice, about which you are so perplexed, if you have neither learned them of others nor discovered them yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: From what you say, I suppose not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: See, again, how inaccurately you speak, Alcibiades!

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: In what respect?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In saying that I say so.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, did you not say that I know nothing of the just and unjust?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No; I did not.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Did I, then?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: How was that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let me explain. Suppose I were to ask you which is the greater number, two or one; you would reply 'two'?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And by how much greater?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: By one.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Which of us now says that two is more than one?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Did not I ask, and you answer the question?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then who is speaking? I who put the question, or you who answer me?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or suppose that I ask and you tell me the letters which make up the name Socrates, which of us is the speaker?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Now let us put the case generally: whenever there is a question and answer, who is the speaker,--the questioner or the answerer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should say, Socrates, that the answerer was the speaker.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And have I not been the questioner all through?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you the answerer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Just so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Which of us, then, was the speaker?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The inference is, Socrates, that I was the speaker.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Did not some one say that Alcibiades, the fair son of Cleinias, not understanding about just and unjust, but thinking that he did understand, was going to the assembly to advise the Athenians about what he did not know? Was not that said?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, Alcibiades, the result may be expressed in the language of Euripides. I think that you have heard all this 'from yourself, and not from me'; nor did I say this, which you erroneously attribute to me, but you yourself, and what you said was very true. For indeed, my dear fellow, the design which you meditate of teaching what you do not know, and have not taken any pains to learn, is downright insanity.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But, Socrates, I think that the Athenians and the rest of the Hellenes do not often advise as to the more just or unjust; for they see no difficulty in them, and therefore they leave them, and consider which course of action will be most expedient; for there is a difference between justice and expediency. Many persons have done great wrong and profited by their injustice; others have done rightly and come to no good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but granting that the just and the expedient are ever so much opposed, you surely do not imagine that you know what is expedient for mankind, or why a thing is expedient?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why not, Socrates?--But I am not going to be asked again from whom I learned, or when I made the discovery.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What a way you have! When you make a mistake which might be refuted by a previous argument, you insist on having a new and different refutation; the old argument is a worn-our garment which you will no longer put on, but some one must produce another which is clean and new. Now I shall disregard this move of yours, and shall ask over again,--Where did you learn and how do you know the nature of the expedient, and who is your teacher? All this I comprehend in a single question, and now you will manifestly be in the old difficulty, and will not be able to show that you know the expedient, either because you learned or because you discovered it yourself. But, as I perceive that you are dainty, and dislike the taste of a stale argument, I will enquire no further into your knowledge of what is expedient or what is not expedient for the Athenian people, and simply request you to say why you do not explain whether justice and expediency are the same or different? And if you like you may examine me as I have examined you, or, if you would rather, you may carry on the discussion by yourself.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But I am not certain, Socrates, whether I shall be able to discuss the matter with you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then imagine, my dear fellow, that I am the demus and the ecclesia; for in the ecclesia, too, you will have to persuade men individually.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not the same person able to persuade one individual singly and many individuals of the things which he knows? The grammarian, for example, can persuade one and he can persuade many about letters.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And about number, will not the same person persuade one and persuade many?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this will be he who knows number, or the arithmetician?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And cannot you persuade one man about that of which you can persuade many?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And that of which you can persuade either is clearly what you know?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the only difference between one who argues as we are doing, and the orator who is addressing an assembly, is that the one seeks to persuade a number, and the other an individual, of the same things.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, since the same person who can persuade a multitude can persuade individuals, try conclusions upon me, and prove to me that the just is not always expedient.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You take liberties, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I shall take the liberty of proving to you the opposite of that which you will not prove to me.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Answer my questions--that is all.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Nay, I should like you to be the speaker.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What, do you not wish to be persuaded?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can you be persuaded better than out of your own mouth?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I think not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you shall answer; and if you do not hear the words, that the just is the expedient, coming from your own lips, never believe another man again.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I won't; but answer I will, for I do not see how I can come to any harm.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A true prophecy! Let me begin then by enquiring of you whether you allow that the just is sometimes expedient and sometimes not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And sometimes honourable and sometimes not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am asking if you ever knew any one who did what was dishonourable and yet just?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Never.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: All just things are honourable?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are honourable things sometimes good and sometimes not good, or are they always good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I rather think, Socrates, that some honourable things are evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are some dishonourable things good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean in such a case as the following:--In time of war, men have been wounded or have died in rescuing a companion or kinsman, when others who have neglected the duty of rescuing them have escaped in safety?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And to rescue another under such circumstances is honourable, in respect of the attempt to save those whom we ought to save; and this is courage?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But evil in respect of death and wounds?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the courage which is shown in the rescue is one thing, and the death another?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the rescue of one's friends is honourable in one point of view, but evil in another?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if honourable, then also good: Will you consider now whether I may not be right, for you were acknowledging that the courage which is shown in the rescue is honourable? Now is this courage good or evil? Look at the matter thus: which would you rather choose, good or evil?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the greatest goods you would be most ready to choose, and would least like to be deprived of them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What would you say of courage? At what price would you be willing to be deprived of courage?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I would rather die than be a coward.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you think that cowardice is the worst of evils?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: As bad as death, I suppose?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And life and courage are the extreme opposites of death and cowardice?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they are what you would most desire to have, and their opposites you would least desire?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is this because you think life and courage the best, and death and cowardice the worst?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you would term the rescue of a friend in battle honourable, in as much as courage does a good work?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But evil because of the death which ensues?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Might we not describe their different effects as follows:--You may call either of them evil in respect of the evil which is the result, and good in respect of the good which is the result of either of them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they are honourable in so far as they are good, and dishonourable in so far as they are evil?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then when you say that the rescue of a friend in battle is honourable and yet evil, that is equivalent to saying that the rescue is good and yet evil?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I believe that you are right, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nothing honourable, regarded as honourable, is evil; nor anything base, regarded as base, good.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Look at the matter yet once more in a further light: he who acts honourably acts well?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And he who acts well is happy?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the happy are those who obtain good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they obtain good by acting well and honourably?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then acting well is a good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And happiness is a good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the good and the honourable are again identified.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Manifestly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, if the argument holds, what we find to be honourable we shall also find to be good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is the good expedient or not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Expedient.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you remember our admissions about the just?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes; if I am not mistaken, we said that those who acted justly must also act honourably.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the honourable is the good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the good is expedient?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, Alcibiades, the just is expedient?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should infer so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And all this I prove out of your own mouth, for I ask and you answer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I must acknowledge it to be true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And having acknowledged that the just is the same as the expedient, are you not (let me ask) prepared to ridicule any one who, pretending to understand the principles of justice and injustice, gets up to advise the noble Athenians or the ignoble Peparethians, that the just may be the evil?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I solemnly declare, Socrates, that I do not know what I am saying. Verily, I am in a strange state, for when you put questions to me I am of different minds in successive instants.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are you not aware of the nature of this perplexity, my friend?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Indeed I am not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you suppose that if some one were to ask you whether you have two eyes or three, or two hands or four, or anything of that sort, you would then be of different minds in successive instants?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I begin to distrust myself, but still I do not suppose that I should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You would feel no doubt; and for this reason--because you would know?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the reason why you involuntarily contradict yourself is clearly that you are ignorant?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very likely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if you are perplexed in answering about just and unjust, honourable and dishonourable, good and evil, expedient and inexpedient, the reason is that you are ignorant of them, and therefore in perplexity. Is not that clear?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But is this always the case, and is a man necessarily perplexed about that of which he has no knowledge?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly he is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you know how to ascend into heaven?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in this case, too, is your judgment perplexed?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you see the reason why, or shall I tell you?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Tell me.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The reason is, that you not only do not know, my friend, but you do not think that you know.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: There again; what do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Ask yourself; are you in any perplexity about things of which you are ignorant? You know, for example, that you know nothing about the preparation of food.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you think and perplex yourself about the preparation of food: or do you leave that to some one who understands the art?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The latter.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or if you were on a voyage, would you bewilder yourself by considering whether the rudder is to be drawn inwards or outwards, or do you leave that to the pilot, and do nothing?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: It would be the concern of the pilot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then you are not perplexed about what you do not know, if you know that you do not know it?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I imagine not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you not see, then, that mistakes in life and practice are likewise to be attributed to the ignorance which has conceit of knowledge?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Once more, what do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I suppose that we begin to act when we think that we know what we are doing?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But when people think that they do not know, they entrust their business to others?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And so there is a class of ignorant persons who do not make mistakes in life, because they trust others about things of which they are ignorant?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Who, then, are the persons who make mistakes? They cannot, of course, be those who know?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if neither those who know, nor those who know that they do not know, make mistakes, there remain those only who do not know and think that they know.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, only those.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then this is ignorance of the disgraceful sort which is mischievous?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And most mischievous and most disgraceful when having to do with the greatest matters?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: By far.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can there be any matters greater than the just, the honourable, the good, and the expedient?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: There cannot be.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And these, as you were saying, are what perplex you?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if you are perplexed, then, as the previous argument has shown, you are not only ignorant of the greatest matters, but being ignorant you fancy that you know them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I fear that you are right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now see what has happened to you, Alcibiades! I hardly like to speak of your evil case, but as we are alone I will: My good friend, you are wedded to ignorance of the most disgraceful kind, and of this you are convicted, not by me, but out of your own mouth and by your own argument; wherefore also you rush into politics before you are educated. Neither is your case to be deemed singular. For I might say the same of almost all our statesmen, with the exception, perhaps of your guardian, Pericles.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates; and Pericles is said not to have got his wisdom by the light of nature, but to have associated with several of the philosophers; with Pythocleides, for example, and with Anaxagoras, and now in advanced life with Damon, in the hope of gaining wisdom.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good; but did you ever know a man wise in anything who was unable to impart his particular wisdom? For example, he who taught you letters was not only wise, but he made you and any others whom he liked wise.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you, whom he taught, can do the same?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in like manner the harper and gymnastic-master?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When a person is enabled to impart knowledge to another, he thereby gives an excellent proof of his own understanding of any matter.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, and did Pericles make any one wise; did he begin by making his sons wise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But, Socrates, if the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, what has that to do with the matter?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but did he make your brother, Cleinias, wise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Cleinias is a madman; there is no use in talking of him.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if Cleinias is a madman and the two sons of Pericles were simpletons, what reason can be given why he neglects you, and lets you be as you are?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I believe that I am to blame for not listening to him.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But did you ever hear of any other Athenian or foreigner, bond or free, who was deemed to have grown wiser in the society of Pericles,--as I might cite Pythodorus, the son of Isolochus, and Callias, the son of Calliades, who have grown wiser in the society of Zeno, for which privilege they have each of them paid him the sum of a hundred minae (about 406 pounds sterling) to the increase of their wisdom and fame.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I certainly never did hear of any one.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, and in reference to your own case, do you mean to remain as you are, or will you take some pains about yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: With your aid, Socrates, I will. And indeed, when I hear you speak, the truth of what you are saying strikes home to me, and I agree with you, for our statesmen, all but a few, do appear to be quite uneducated.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What is the inference?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, that if they were educated they would be trained athletes, and he who means to rival them ought to have knowledge and experience when he attacks them; but now, as they have become politicians without any special training, why should I have the trouble of learning and practising? For I know well that by the light of nature I shall get the better of them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: My dear friend, what a sentiment! And how unworthy of your noble form and your high estate!

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What do you mean, Socrates; why do you say so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am grieved when I think of our mutual love.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: At what?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: At your fancying that the contest on which you are entering is with people here.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, what others are there?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is that a question which a magnanimous soul should ask?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Do you mean to say that the contest is not with these?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And suppose that you were going to steer a ship into action, would you only aim at being the best pilot on board? Would you not, while acknowledging that you must possess this degree of excellence, rather look to your antagonists, and not, as you are now doing, to your fellow combatants? You ought to be so far above these latter, that they will not even dare to be your rivals; and, being regarded by you as inferiors, will do battle for you against the enemy; this is the kind of superiority which you must establish over them, if you mean to accomplish any noble action really worthy of yourself and of the state.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That would certainly be my aim.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Verily, then, you have good reason to be satisfied, if you are better than the soldiers; and you need not, when you are their superior and have your thoughts and actions fixed upon them, look away to the generals of the enemy.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Of whom are you speaking, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, you surely know that our city goes to war now and then with the Lacedaemonians and with the great king?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True enough.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if you meant to be the ruler of this city, would you not be right in considering that the Lacedaemonian and Persian king were your true rivals?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I believe that you are right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Oh no, my friend, I am quite wrong, and I think that you ought rather to turn your attention to Midias the quail-breeder and others like him, who manage our politics; in whom, as the women would remark, you may still see the slaves' cut of hair, cropping out in their minds as well as on their pates; and they come with their barbarous lingo to flatter us and not to rule us. To these, I say, you should look, and then you need not trouble yourself about your own fitness to contend in such a noble arena: there is no reason why you should either learn what has to be learned, or practise what has to be practised, and only when thoroughly prepared enter on a political career.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: There, I think, Socrates, that you are right; I do not suppose, however, that the Spartan generals or the great king are really different from anybody else.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But, my dear friend, do consider what you are saying.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What am I to consider?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In the first place, will you be more likely to take care of yourself, if you are in a wholesome fear and dread of them, or if you are not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly, if I have such a fear of them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you think that you will sustain any injury if you take care of yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No, I shall be greatly benefited.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this is one very important respect in which that notion of yours is bad.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In the next place, consider that what you say is probably false.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let me ask you whether better natures are likely to be found in noble races or not in noble races?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly in noble races.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Are not those who are well born and well bred most likely to be perfect in virtue?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then let us compare our antecedents with those of the Lacedaemonian and Persian kings; are they inferior to us in descent? Have we not heard that the former are sprung from Heracles, and the latter from Achaemenes, and that the race of Heracles and the race of Achaemenes go back to Perseus, son of Zeus?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Why, so does mine go back to Eurysaces, and he to Zeus!

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And mine, noble Alcibiades, to Daedalus, and he to Hephaestus, son of Zeus. But, for all that, we are far inferior to them. For they are descended 'from Zeus,' through a line of kings--either kings of Argos and Lacedaemon, or kings of Persia, a country which the descendants of Achaemenes have always possessed, besides being at various times sovereigns of Asia, as they now are; whereas, we and our fathers were but private persons. How ridiculous would you be thought if you were to make a display of your ancestors and of Salamis the island of Eurysaces, or of Aegina, the habitation of the still more ancient Aeacus, before Artaxerxes, son of Xerxes. You should consider how inferior we are to them both in the derivation of our birth and in other particulars. Did you never observe how great is the property of the Spartan kings? And their wives are under the guardianship of the Ephori, who are public officers and watch over them, in order to preserve as far as possible the purity of the Heracleid blood. Still greater is the difference among the Persians; for no one entertains a suspicion that the father of a prince of Persia can be any one but the king. Such is the awe which invests the person of the queen, that any other guard is needless. And when the heir of the kingdom is born, all the subjects of the king feast; and the day of his birth is for ever afterwards kept as a holiday and time of sacrifice by all Asia; whereas, when you and I were born, Alcibiades, as the comic poet says, the neighbours hardly knew of the important event. After the birth of the royal child, he is tended, not by a good-for-nothing woman-nurse, but by the best of the royal eunuchs, who are charged with the care of him, and especially with the fashioning and right formation of his limbs, in order that he may be as shapely as possible; which being their calling, they are held in great honour. And when the young prince is seven years old he is put upon a horse and taken to the riding-masters, and begins to go out hunting. And at fourteen years of age he is handed over to the royal schoolmasters, as they are termed: these are four chosen men, reputed to be the best among the Persians of a certain age; and one of them is the wisest, another the justest, a third the most temperate, and a fourth the most valiant. The first instructs him in the magianism of Zoroaster, the son of Oromasus, which is the worship of the Gods, and teaches him also the duties of his royal office; the second, who is the justest, teaches him always to speak the truth; the third, or most temperate, forbids him to allow any pleasure to be lord over him, that he may be accustomed to be a freeman and king indeed,--lord of himself first, and not a slave; the most valiant trains him to be bold and fearless, telling him that if he fears he is to deem himself a slave; whereas Pericles gave you, Alcibiades, for a tutor Zopyrus the Thracian, a slave of his who was past all other work. I might enlarge on the nurture and education of your rivals, but that would be tedious; and what I have said is a sufficient sample of what remains to be said. I have only to remark, by way of contrast, that no one cares about your birth or nurture or education, or, I may say, about that of any other Athenian, unless he has a lover who looks after him. And if you cast an eye on the wealth, the luxury, the garments with their flowing trains, the anointings with myrrh, the multitudes of attendants, and all the other bravery of the Persians, you will be ashamed when you discern your own inferiority; or if you look at the temperance and orderliness and ease and grace and magnanimity and courage and endurance and love of toil and desire of glory and ambition of the Lacedaemonians--in all these respects you will see that you are but a child in comparison of them. Even in the matter of wealth, if you value yourself upon that, I must reveal to you how you stand; for if you form an estimate of the wealth of the Lacedaemonians, you will see that our possessions fall far short of theirs. For no one here can compete with them either in the extent and fertility of their own and the Messenian territory, or in the number of their slaves, and especially of the Helots, or of their horses, or of the animals which feed on the Messenian pastures. But I have said enough of this: and as to gold and silver, there is more of them in Lacedaemon than in all the rest of Hellas, for during many generations gold has been always flowing in to them from the whole Hellenic world, and often from the barbarian also, and never going out, as in the fable of Aesop the fox said to the lion, 'The prints of the feet of those going in are distinct enough;' but who ever saw the trace of money going out of Lacedaemon? And therefore you may safely infer that the inhabitants are the richest of the Hellenes in gold and silver, and that their kings are the richest of them, for they have a larger share of these things, and they have also a tribute paid to them which is very considerable. Yet the Spartan wealth, though great in comparison of the wealth of the other Hellenes, is as nothing in comparison of that of the Persians and their kings. Why, I have been informed by a credible person who went up to the king (at Susa), that he passed through a large tract of excellent land, extending for nearly a day's journey, which the people of the country called the queen's girdle, and another, which they called her veil; and several other fair and fertile districts, which were reserved for the adornment of the queen, and are named after her several habiliments. Now, I cannot help thinking to myself, What if some one were to go to Amestris, the wife of Xerxes and mother of Artaxerxes, and say to her, There is a certain Dinomache, whose whole wardrobe is not worth fifty minae--and that will be more than the value--and she has a son who is possessed of a three-hundred acre patch at Erchiae, and he has a mind to go to war with your son--would she not wonder to what this Alcibiades trusts for success in the conflict? 'He must rely,' she would say to herself, 'upon his training and wisdom--these are the things which Hellenes value.' And if she heard that this Alcibiades who is making the attempt is not as yet twenty years old, and is wholly uneducated, and when his lover tells him that he ought to get education and training first, and then go and fight the king, he refuses, and says that he is well enough as he is, would she not be amazed, and ask 'On what, then, does the youth rely?' And if we replied: He relies on his beauty, and stature, and birth, and mental endowments, she would think that we were mad, Alcibiades, when she compared the advantages which you possess with those of her own people. And I believe that even Lampido, the daughter of Leotychides, the wife of Archidamus and mother of Agis, all of whom were kings, would have the same feeling; if, in your present uneducated state, you were to turn your thoughts against her son, she too would be equally astonished. But how disgraceful, that we should not have as high a notion of what is required in us as our enemies' wives and mothers have of the qualities which are required in their assailants! O my friend, be persuaded by me, and hear the Delphian inscription, 'Know thyself'--not the men whom you think, but these kings are our rivals, and we can only overcome them by pains and skill. And if you fail in the required qualities, you will fail also in becoming renowned among Hellenes and Barbarians, which you seem to desire more than any other man ever desired anything.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I entirely believe you; but what are the sort of pains which are required, Socrates,--can you tell me?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, I can; but we must take counsel together concerning the manner in which both of us may be most improved. For what I am telling you of the necessity of education applies to myself as well as to you; and there is only one point in which I have an advantage over you.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have a guardian who is better and wiser than your guardian, Pericles.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Who is he, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: God, Alcibiades, who up to this day has not allowed me to converse with you; and he inspires in me the faith that I am especially designed to bring you to honour.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You are jesting, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Perhaps, at any rate, I am right in saying that all men greatly need pains and care, and you and I above all men.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You are not far wrong about me.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And certainly not about myself.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But what can we do?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There must be no hesitation or cowardice, my friend.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That would not become us, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No, indeed, and we ought to take counsel together: for do we not wish to be as good as possible?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: We do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In what sort of virtue?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Plainly, in the virtue of good men.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Who are good in what?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Those, clearly, who are good in the management of affairs.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What sort of affairs? Equestrian affairs?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean that about them we should have recourse to horsemen?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, naval affairs?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean that we should have recourse to sailors about them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what affairs? And who do them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The affairs which occupy Athenian gentlemen.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when you speak of gentlemen, do you mean the wise or the unwise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The wise.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And a man is good in respect of that in which he is wise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And evil in respect of that in which he is unwise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The shoemaker, for example, is wise in respect of the making of shoes?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he is good in that?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: He is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But in respect of the making of garments he is unwise?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then in that he is bad?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then upon this view of the matter the same man is good and also bad?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But would you say that the good are the same as the bad?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then whom do you call the good?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I mean by the good those who are able to rule in the city.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Not, surely, over horses?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But over men?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When they are sick?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or on a voyage?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or reaping the harvest?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When they are doing something or nothing?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: When they are doing something, I should say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I wish that you would explain to me what this something is.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: When they are having dealings with one another, and using one another's services, as we citizens do in our daily life.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Those of whom you speak are ruling over men who are using the services of other men?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Are they ruling over the signal-men who give the time to the rowers?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No; they are not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That would be the office of the pilot?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But, perhaps you mean that they rule over flute-players, who lead the singers and use the services of the dancers?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That would be the business of the teacher of the chorus?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what is the meaning of being able to rule over men who use other men?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I mean that they rule over men who have common rights of citizenship, and dealings with one another.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what sort of an art is this? Suppose that I ask you again, as I did just now, What art makes men know how to rule over their fellow-sailors,--how would you answer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The art of the pilot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And, if I may recur to another old instance, what art enables them to rule over their fellow-singers?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The art of the teacher of the chorus, which you were just now mentioning.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what do you call the art of fellow-citizens?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should say, good counsel, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is the art of the pilot evil counsel?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But good counsel?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes, that is what I should say,--good counsel, of which the aim is the preservation of the voyagers.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: True. And what is the aim of that other good counsel of which you speak?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The aim is the better order and preservation of the city.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what is that of which the absence or presence improves and preserves the order of the city? Suppose you were to ask me, what is that of which the presence or absence improves or preserves the order of the body? I should reply, the presence of health and the absence of disease. You would say the same?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if you were to ask me the same question about the eyes, I should reply in the same way, 'the presence of sight and the absence of blindness;' or about the ears, I should reply, that they were improved and were in better case, when deafness was absent, and hearing was present in them.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what would you say of a state? What is that by the presence or absence of which the state is improved and better managed and ordered?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should say, Socrates:--the presence of friendship and the absence of hatred and division.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do you mean by friendship agreement or disagreement?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Agreement.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What art makes cities agree about numbers?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Arithmetic.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And private individuals?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The same.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what art makes each individual agree with himself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: The same.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what art makes each of us agree with himself about the comparative length of the span and of the cubit? Does not the art of measure?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Individuals are agreed with one another about this; and states, equally?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the same holds of the balance?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But what is the other agreement of which you speak, and about what? what art can give that agreement? And does that which gives it to the state give it also to the individual, so as to make him consistent with himself and with another?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should suppose so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But what is the nature of the agreement?--answer, and faint not.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I mean to say that there should be such friendship and agreement as exists between an affectionate father and mother and their son, or between brothers, or between husband and wife.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But can a man, Alcibiades, agree with a woman about the spinning of wool, which she understands and he does not?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No, truly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor has he any need, for spinning is a female accomplishment.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And would a woman agree with a man about the science of arms, which she has never learned?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I suppose that the use of arms would be regarded by you as a male accomplishment?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: It would.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, upon your view, women and men have two sorts of knowledge?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then in their knowledge there is no agreement of women and men?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: There is not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor can there be friendship, if friendship is agreement?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Plainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then women are not loved by men when they do their own work?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor men by women when they do their own work?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor are states well administered, when individuals do their own work?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should rather think, Socrates, that the reverse is the truth. (Compare Republic.)

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What! do you mean to say that states are well administered when friendship is absent, the presence of which, as we were saying, alone secures their good order?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But I should say that there is friendship among them, for this very reason, that the two parties respectively do their own work.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That was not what you were saying before; and what do you mean now by affirming that friendship exists when there is no agreement? How can there be agreement about matters which the one party knows, and of which the other is in ignorance?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when individuals are doing their own work, are they doing what is just or unjust?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What is just, certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when individuals do what is just in the state, is there no friendship among them?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I suppose that there must be, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what do you mean by this friendship or agreement about which we must be wise and discreet in order that we may be good men? I cannot make out where it exists or among whom; according to you, the same persons may sometimes have it, and sometimes not.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: But, indeed, Socrates, I do not know what I am saying; and I have long been, unconsciously to myself, in a most disgraceful state.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nevertheless, cheer up; at fifty, if you had discovered your deficiency, you would have been too old, and the time for taking care of yourself would have passed away, but yours is just the age at which the discovery should be made.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: And what should he do, Socrates, who would make the discovery?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Answer questions, Alcibiades; and that is a process which, by the grace of God, if I may put any faith in my oracle, will be very improving to both of us.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: If I can be improved by answering, I will answer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And first of all, that we may not peradventure be deceived by appearances, fancying, perhaps, that we are taking care of ourselves when we are not, what is the meaning of a man taking care of himself? and when does he take care? Does he take care of himself when he takes care of what belongs to him?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I should think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When does a man take care of his feet? Does he not take care of them when he takes care of that which belongs to his feet?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do not understand.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let me take the hand as an illustration; does not a ring belong to the finger, and to the finger only?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the shoe in like manner to the foot?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when we take care of our shoes, do we not take care of our feet?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do not comprehend, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But you would admit, Alcibiades, that to take proper care of a thing is a correct expression?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And taking proper care means improving?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what is the art which improves our shoes?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Shoemaking.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then by shoemaking we take care of our shoes?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do we by shoemaking take care of our feet, or by some other art which improves the feet?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: By some other art.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the same art improves the feet which improves the rest of the body?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Which is gymnastic?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then by gymnastic we take care of our feet, and by shoemaking of that which belongs to our feet?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And by gymnastic we take care of our hands, and by the art of graving rings of that which belongs to our hands?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And by gymnastic we take care of the body, and by the art of weaving and the other arts we take care of the things of the body?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the art which takes care of each thing is different from that which takes care of the belongings of each thing?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then in taking care of what belongs to you, you do not take care of yourself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: For the art which takes care of our belongings appears not to be the same as that which takes care of ourselves?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Clearly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now let me ask you what is the art with which we take care of ourselves?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I cannot say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: At any rate, thus much has been admitted, that the art is not one which makes any of our possessions, but which makes ourselves better?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But should we ever have known what art makes a shoe better, if we did not know a shoe?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor should we know what art makes a ring better, if we did not know a ring?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That is true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can we ever know what art makes a man better, if we do not know what we are ourselves?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is self-knowledge such an easy thing, and was he to be lightly esteemed who inscribed the text on the temple at Delphi? Or is self-knowledge a difficult thing, which few are able to attain?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: At times I fancy, Socrates, that anybody can know himself; at other times the task appears to be very difficult.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But whether easy or difficult, Alcibiades, still there is no other way; knowing what we are, we shall know how to take care of ourselves, and if we are ignorant we shall not know.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: That is true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, let us see in what way the self-existent can be discovered by us; that will give us a chance of discovering our own existence, which otherwise we can never know.

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: You say truly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Come, now, I beseech you, tell me with whom you are conversing?--with whom but with me?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: As I am, with you?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That is to say, I, Socrates, am talking?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And Alcibiades is my hearer?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And I in talking use words?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And talking and using words have, I suppose, the same meaning?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the user is not the same as the thing which he uses?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will explain; the shoemaker, for example, uses a square tool, and a circular tool, and other tools for cutting?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But the tool is not the same as the cutter and user of the tool?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in the same way the instrument of the harper is to be distinguished from the harper himself?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Now the question which I asked was whether you conceive the user to be always different from that which he uses?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what shall we say of the shoemaker? Does he cut with his tools only or with his hands?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: With his hands as well.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He uses his hands too?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And does he use his eyes in cutting leather?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: He does.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And we admit that the user is not the same with the things which he uses?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the shoemaker and the harper are to be distinguished from the hands and feet which they use?

Speaker: ALCIBIADES
