Dialogue: And would you tell me again, sweet Socrates, which of the aforesaid classes is the mixed one?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will, my fine fellow, to the best of my ability.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us then understand the mixed class to be that which we placed third in the list of four.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That which followed the infinite and the finite; and in which you ranked health, and, if I am not mistaken, harmony.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Capital; and now will you please to give me your best attention?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Proceed; I am attending.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I say that when the harmony in animals is dissolved, there is also a dissolution of nature and a generation of pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is very probable.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the restoration of harmony and return to nature is the source of pleasure, if I may be allowed to speak in the fewest and shortest words about matters of the greatest moment.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I believe that you are right, Socrates; but will you try to be a little plainer?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do not obvious and every-day phenomena furnish the simplest illustration?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What phenomena do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Hunger, for example, is a dissolution and a pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whereas eating is a replenishment and a pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Thirst again is a destruction and a pain, but the effect of moisture replenishing the dry place is a pleasure: once more, the unnatural separation and dissolution caused by heat is painful, and the natural restoration and refrigeration is pleasant.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the unnatural freezing of the moisture in an animal is pain, and the natural process of resolution and return of the elements to their original state is pleasure. And would not the general proposition seem to you to hold, that the destroying of the natural union of the finite and infinite, which, as I was observing before, make up the class of living beings, is pain, and that the process of return of all things to their own nature is pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Granted; what you say has a general truth.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Here then is one kind of pleasures and pains originating severally in the two processes which we have described?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us next assume that in the soul herself there is an antecedent hope of pleasure which is sweet and refreshing, and an expectation of pain, fearful and anxious.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes; this is another class of pleasures and pains, which is of the soul only, apart from the body, and is produced by expectation.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Right; for in the analysis of these, pure, as I suppose them to be, the pleasures being unalloyed with pain and the pains with pleasure, methinks that we shall see clearly whether the whole class of pleasure is to be desired, or whether this quality of entire desirableness is not rather to be attributed to another of the classes which have been mentioned; and whether pleasure and pain, like heat and cold, and other things of the same kind, are not sometimes to be desired and sometimes not to be desired, as being not in themselves good, but only sometimes and in some instances admitting of the nature of good.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You say most truly that this is the track which the investigation should pursue.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, assuming that pain ensues on the dissolution, and pleasure on the restoration of the harmony, let us now ask what will be the condition of animated beings who are neither in process of restoration nor of dissolution. And mind what you say: I ask whether any animal who is in that condition can possibly have any feeling of pleasure or pain, great or small?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then here we have a third state, over and above that of pleasure and of pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do not forget that there is such a state; it will make a great difference in our judgment of pleasure, whether we remember this or not. And I should like to say a few words about it.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What have you to say?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, you know that if a man chooses the life of wisdom, there is no reason why he should not live in this neutral state.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You mean that he may live neither rejoicing nor sorrowing?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes; and if I remember rightly, when the lives were compared, no degree of pleasure, whether great or small, was thought to be necessary to him who chose the life of thought and wisdom.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, certainly, we said so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he will live without pleasure; and who knows whether this may not be the most divine of all lives?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: If so, the gods, at any rate, cannot be supposed to have either joy or sorrow.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Certainly not--there would be a great impropriety in the assumption of either alternative. But whether the gods are or are not indifferent to pleasure is a point which may be considered hereafter if in any way relevant to the argument, and whatever is the conclusion we will place it to the account of mind in her contest for the second place, should she have to resign the first.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Just so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The other class of pleasures, which as we were saying is purely mental, is entirely derived from memory.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I must first of all analyze memory, or rather perception which is prior to memory, if the subject of our discussion is ever to be properly cleared up.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How will you proceed?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us imagine affections of the body which are extinguished before they reach the soul, and leave her unaffected; and again, other affections which vibrate through both soul and body, and impart a shock to both and to each of them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Granted.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the soul may be truly said to be oblivious of the first but not of the second?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When I say oblivious, do not suppose that I mean forgetfulness in a literal sense; for forgetfulness is the exit of memory, which in this case has not yet entered; and to speak of the loss of that which is not yet in existence, and never has been, is a contradiction; do you see?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then just be so good as to change the terms.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How shall I change them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Instead of the oblivion of the soul, when you are describing the state in which she is unaffected by the shocks of the body, say unconsciousness.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the union or communion of soul and body in one feeling and motion would be properly called consciousness?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now we know the meaning of the word?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And memory may, I think, be rightly described as the preservation of consciousness?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But do we not distinguish memory from recollection?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do we not mean by recollection the power which the soul has of recovering, when by herself, some feeling which she experienced when in company with the body?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when she recovers of herself the lost recollection of some consciousness or knowledge, the recovery is termed recollection and reminiscence?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is a reason why I say all this.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I want to attain the plainest possible notion of pleasure and desire, as they exist in the mind only, apart from the body; and the previous analysis helps to show the nature of both.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Then now, Socrates, let us proceed to the next point.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There are certainly many things to be considered in discussing the generation and whole complexion of pleasure. At the outset we must determine the nature and seat of desire.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Ay; let us enquire into that, for we shall lose nothing.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nay, Protarchus, we shall surely lose the puzzle if we find the answer.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: A fair retort; but let us proceed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Did we not place hunger, thirst, and the like, in the class of desires?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet they are very different; what common nature have we in view when we call them by a single name?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: By heavens, Socrates, that is a question which is not easily answered; but it must be answered.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then let us go back to our examples.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Where shall we begin?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do we mean anything when we say 'a man thirsts'?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We mean to say that he 'is empty'?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not thirst desire?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, of drink.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Would you say of drink, or of replenishment with drink?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I should say, of replenishment with drink.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he who is empty desires, as would appear, the opposite of what he experiences; for he is empty and desires to be full?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But how can a man who is empty for the first time, attain either by perception or memory to any apprehension of replenishment, of which he has no present or past experience?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet he who desires, surely desires something?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He does not desire that which he experiences, for he experiences thirst, and thirst is emptiness; but he desires replenishment?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then there must be something in the thirsty man which in some way apprehends replenishment?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: There must.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And that cannot be the body, for the body is supposed to be emptied?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The only remaining alternative is that the soul apprehends the replenishment by the help of memory; as is obvious, for what other way can there be?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I cannot imagine any other.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But do you see the consequence?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That there is no such thing as desire of the body.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, because the argument shows that the endeavour of every animal is to the reverse of his bodily state.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the impulse which leads him to the opposite of what he is experiencing proves that he has a memory of the opposite state.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the argument, having proved that memory attracts us towards the objects of desire, proves also that the impulses and the desires and the moving principle in every living being have their origin in the soul.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The argument will not allow that our body either hungers or thirsts or has any similar experience.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let me make a further observation; the argument appears to me to imply that there is a kind of life which consists in these affections.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of what affections, and of what kind of life, are you speaking?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am speaking of being emptied and replenished, and of all that relates to the preservation and destruction of living beings, as well as of the pain which is felt in one of these states and of the pleasure which succeeds to it.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And what would you say of the intermediate state?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What do you mean by 'intermediate'?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean when a person is in actual suffering and yet remembers past pleasures which, if they would only return, would relieve him; but as yet he has them not. May we not say of him, that he is in an intermediate state?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Would you say that he was wholly pained or wholly pleased?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Nay, I should say that he has two pains; in his body there is the actual experience of pain, and in his soul longing and expectation.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What do you mean, Protarchus, by the two pains? May not a man who is empty have at one time a sure hope of being filled, and at other times be quite in despair?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And has he not the pleasure of memory when he is hoping to be filled, and yet in that he is empty is he not at the same time in pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then man and the other animals have at the same time both pleasure and pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I suppose so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But when a man is empty and has no hope of being filled, there will be the double experience of pain. You observed this and inferred that the double experience was the single case possible.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Shall the enquiry into these states of feeling be made the occasion of raising a question?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What question?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whether we ought to say that the pleasures and pains of which we are speaking are true or false? or some true and some false?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: But how, Socrates, can there be false pleasures and pains?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how, Protarchus, can there be true and false fears, or true and false expectations, or true and false opinions?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I grant that opinions may be true or false, but not pleasures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: What do you mean? I am afraid that we are raising a very serious enquiry.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: There I agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, my boy, for you are one of Philebus' boys, the point to be considered, is, whether the enquiry is relevant to the argument.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Surely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No tedious and irrelevant discussion can be allowed; what is said should be pertinent.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am always wondering at the question which has now been raised.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you deny that some pleasures are false, and others true?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: To be sure I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Would you say that no one ever seemed to rejoice and yet did not rejoice, or seemed to feel pain and yet did not feel pain, sleeping or waking, mad or lunatic?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: So we have always held, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But were you right? Shall we enquire into the truth of your opinion?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I think that we should.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us then put into more precise terms the question which has arisen about pleasure and opinion. Is there such a thing as opinion?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And such a thing as pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And an opinion must be of something?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And a man must be pleased by something?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite correct.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And whether the opinion be right or wrong, makes no difference; it will still be an opinion?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And he who is pleased, whether he is rightly pleased or not, will always have a real feeling of pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes; that is also quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, how can opinion be both true and false, and pleasure true only, although pleasure and opinion are both equally real?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes; that is the question.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean that opinion admits of truth and falsehood, and hence becomes not merely opinion, but opinion of a certain quality; and this is what you think should be examined?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And further, even if we admit the existence of qualities in other objects, may not pleasure and pain be simple and devoid of quality?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But there is no difficulty in seeing that pleasure and pain as well as opinion have qualities, for they are great or small, and have various degrees of intensity; as was indeed said long ago by us.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if badness attaches to any of them, Protarchus, then we should speak of a bad opinion or of a bad pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if rightness attaches to any of them, should we not speak of a right opinion or right pleasure; and in like manner of the reverse of rightness?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if the thing opined be erroneous, might we not say that the opinion, being erroneous, is not right or rightly opined?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if we see a pleasure or pain which errs in respect of its object, shall we call that right or good, or by any honourable name?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Not if the pleasure is mistaken; how could we?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And surely pleasure often appears to accompany an opinion which is not true, but false?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly it does; and in that case, Socrates, as we were saying, the opinion is false, but no one could call the actual pleasure false.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: How eagerly, Protarchus, do you rush to the defence of pleasure!

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Nay, Socrates, I only repeat what I hear.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is there no difference, my friend, between that pleasure which is associated with right opinion and knowledge, and that which is often found in all of us associated with falsehood and ignorance?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: There must be a very great difference, between them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, now let us proceed to contemplate this difference.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Lead, and I will follow.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, my view is--

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We agree--do we not?--that there is such a thing as false, and also such a thing as true opinion?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And pleasure and pain, as I was just now saying, are often consequent upon these--upon true and false opinion, I mean.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do not opinion and the endeavour to form an opinion always spring from memory and perception?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Might we imagine the process to be something of this nature?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of what nature?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: An object may be often seen at a distance not very clearly, and the seer may want to determine what it is which he sees.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very likely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Soon he begins to interrogate himself.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: In what manner?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He asks himself--'What is that which appears to be standing by the rock under the tree?' This is the question which he may be supposed to put to himself when he sees such an appearance.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: To which he may guess the right answer, saying as if in a whisper to himself--'It is a man.'

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Or again, he may be misled, and then he will say--'No, it is a figure made by the shepherds.'

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And if he has a companion, he repeats his thought to him in articulate sounds, and what was before an opinion, has now become a proposition.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if he be walking alone when these thoughts occur to him, he may not unfrequently keep them in his mind for a considerable time.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, now, I wonder whether you would agree in my explanation of this phenomenon.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is your explanation?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I think that the soul at such times is like a book.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Memory and perception meet, and they and their attendant feelings seem to almost to write down words in the soul, and when the inscribing feeling writes truly, then true opinion and true propositions which are the expressions of opinion come into our souls--but when the scribe within us writes falsely, the result is false.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I quite assent and agree to your statement.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I must bespeak your favour also for another artist, who is busy at the same time in the chambers of the soul.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The painter, who, after the scribe has done his work, draws images in the soul of the things which he has described.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: But when and how does he do this?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When a man, besides receiving from sight or some other sense certain opinions or statements, sees in his mind the images of the subjects of them;--is not this a very common mental phenomenon?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the images answering to true opinions and words are true, and to false opinions and words false; are they not?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: They are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If we are right so far, there arises a further question.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whether we experience the feeling of which I am speaking only in relation to the present and the past, or in relation to the future also?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I should say in relation to all times alike.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Have not purely mental pleasures and pains been described already as in some cases anticipations of the bodily ones; from which we may infer that anticipatory pleasures and pains have to do with the future?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do all those writings and paintings which, as we were saying a little while ago, are produced in us, relate to the past and present only, and not to the future?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: To the future, very much.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When you say, 'Very much,' you mean to imply that all these representations are hopes about the future, and that mankind are filled with hopes in every stage of existence?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Answer me another question.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What question?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A just and pious and good man is the friend of the gods; is he not?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly he is.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the unjust and utterly bad man is the reverse?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And all men, as we were saying just now, are always filled with hopes?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And these hopes, as they are termed, are propositions which exist in the minds of each of us?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the fancies of hope are also pictured in us; a man may often have a vision of a heap of gold, and pleasures ensuing, and in the picture there may be a likeness of himself mightily rejoicing over his good fortune.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And may we not say that the good, being friends of the gods, have generally true pictures presented to them, and the bad false pictures?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The bad, too, have pleasures painted in their fancy as well as the good; but I presume that they are false pleasures.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: They are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The bad then commonly delight in false pleasures, and the good in true pleasures?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Doubtless.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then upon this view there are false pleasures in the souls of men which are a ludicrous imitation of the true, and there are pains of a similar character?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: There are.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And did we not allow that a man who had an opinion at all had a real opinion, but often about things which had no existence either in the past, present, or future?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And this was the source of false opinion and opining; am I not right?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And must we not attribute to pleasure and pain a similar real but illusory character?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean to say that a man must be admitted to have real pleasure who is pleased with anything or anyhow; and he may be pleased about things which neither have nor have ever had any real existence, and, more often than not, are never likely to exist.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates, that again is undeniable.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And may not the same be said about fear and anger and the like; are they not often false?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can opinions be good or bad except in as far as they are true or false?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: In no other way.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Nor can pleasures be conceived to be bad except in so far as they are false.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Nay, Socrates, that is the very opposite of truth; for no one would call pleasures and pains bad because they are false, but by reason of some other great corruption to which they are liable.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, of pleasures which are corrupt and caused by corruption we will hereafter speak, if we care to continue the enquiry; for the present I would rather show by another argument that there are many false pleasures existing or coming into existence in us, because this may assist our final decision.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true; that is to say, if there are such pleasures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I think that there are, Protarchus; but this is an opinion which should be well assured, and not rest upon a mere assertion.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now, like wrestlers, let us approach and grasp this new argument.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We were maintaining a little while since, that when desires, as they are termed, exist in us, then the body has separate feelings apart from the soul--do you remember?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, I remember that you said so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the soul was supposed to desire the opposite of the bodily state, while the body was the source of any pleasure or pain which was experienced.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now you may infer what happens in such cases.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What am I to infer?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That in such cases pleasures and pains come simultaneously; and there is a juxtaposition of the opposite sensations which correspond to them, as has been already shown.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And there is another point to which we have agreed.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That pleasure and pain both admit of more and less, and that they are of the class of infinites.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly, we said so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But how can we rightly judge of them?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How can we?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is it our intention to judge of their comparative importance and intensity, measuring pleasure against pain, and pain against pain, and pleasure against pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, such is our intention, and we shall judge of them accordingly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, take the case of sight. Does not the nearness or distance of magnitudes obscure their true proportions, and make us opine falsely; and do we not find the same illusion happening in the case of pleasures and pains?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, Socrates, and in a degree far greater.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then what we are now saying is the opposite of what we were saying before.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the opinions were true and false, and infected the pleasures and pains with their own falsity.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But now it is the pleasures which are said to be true and false because they are seen at various distances, and subjected to comparison; the pleasures appear to be greater and more vehement when placed side by side with the pains, and the pains when placed side by side with the pleasures.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly, and for the reason which you mention.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And suppose you part off from pleasures and pains the element which makes them appear to be greater or less than they really are: you will acknowledge that this element is illusory, and you will never say that the corresponding excess or defect of pleasure or pain is real or true.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Next let us see whether in another direction we may not find pleasures and pains existing and appearing in living beings, which are still more false than these.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What are they, and how shall we find them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If I am not mistaken, I have often repeated that pains and aches and suffering and uneasiness of all sorts arise out of a corruption of nature caused by concretions, and dissolutions, and repletions, and evacuations, and also by growth and decay?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, that has been often said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And we have also agreed that the restoration of the natural state is pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But now let us suppose an interval of time at which the body experiences none of these changes.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: When can that be, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Your question, Protarchus, does not help the argument.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Why not, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Because it does not prevent me from repeating mine.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: And what was that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, Protarchus, admitting that there is no such interval, I may ask what would be the necessary consequence if there were?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You mean, what would happen if the body were not changed either for good or bad?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Why then, Socrates, I should suppose that there would be neither pleasure nor pain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good; but still, if I am not mistaken, you do assert that we must always be experiencing one of them; that is what the wise tell us; for, say they, all things are ever flowing up and down.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, and their words are of no mean authority.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Of course, for they are no mean authorities themselves; and I should like to avoid the brunt of their argument. Shall I tell you how I mean to escape from them? And you shall be the partner of my flight.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: To them we will say: 'Good; but are we, or living things in general, always conscious of what happens to us--for example, of our growth, or the like? Are we not, on the contrary, almost wholly unconscious of this and similar phenomena?' You must answer for them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: The latter alternative is the true one.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then we were not right in saying, just now, that motions going up and down cause pleasures and pains?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: A better and more unexceptionable way of speaking will be--

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: If we say that the great changes produce pleasures and pains, but that the moderate and lesser ones do neither.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That, Socrates, is the more correct mode of speaking.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if this be true, the life to which I was just now referring again appears.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What life?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The life which we affirmed to be devoid either of pain or of joy.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We may assume then that there are three lives, one pleasant, one painful, and the third which is neither; what say you?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I should say as you do that there are three of them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But if so, the negation of pain will not be the same with pleasure.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then when you hear a person saying, that always to live without pain is the pleasantest of all things, what would you understand him to mean by that statement?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I think that by pleasure he must mean the negative of pain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us take any three things; or suppose that we embellish a little and call the first gold, the second silver, and there shall be a third which is neither.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Now, can that which is neither be either gold or silver?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: No more can that neutral or middle life be rightly or reasonably spoken or thought of as pleasant or painful.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, my friend, there are, as we know, persons who say and think so.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do they think that they have pleasure when they are free from pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: They say so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And they must think or they would not say that they have pleasure.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I suppose not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet if pleasure and the negation of pain are of distinct natures, they are wrong.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: But they are undoubtedly of distinct natures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then shall we take the view that they are three, as we were just now saying, or that they are two only--the one being a state of pain, which is an evil, and the other a cessation of pain, which is of itself a good, and is called pleasant?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: But why, Socrates, do we ask the question at all? I do not see the reason.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You, Protarchus, have clearly never heard of certain enemies of our friend Philebus.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: And who may they be?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Certain persons who are reputed to be masters in natural philosophy, who deny the very existence of pleasure.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Indeed!

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: They say that what the school of Philebus calls pleasures are all of them only avoidances of pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: And would you, Socrates, have us agree with them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, no, I would rather use them as a sort of diviners, who divine the truth, not by rules of art, but by an instinctive repugnance and extreme detestation which a noble nature has of the power of pleasure, in which they think that there is nothing sound, and her seductive influence is declared by them to be witchcraft, and not pleasure. This is the use which you may make of them. And when you have considered the various grounds of their dislike, you shall hear from me what I deem to be true pleasures. Having thus examined the nature of pleasure from both points of view, we will bring her up for judgment.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Well said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then let us enter into an alliance with these philosophers and follow in the track of their dislike. I imagine that they would say something of this sort; they would begin at the beginning, and ask whether, if we wanted to know the nature of any quality, such as hardness, we should be more likely to discover it by looking at the hardest things, rather than at the least hard? You, Protarchus, shall answer these severe gentlemen as you answer me.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: By all means, and I reply to them, that you should look at the greatest instances.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then if we want to see the true nature of pleasures as a class, we should not look at the most diluted pleasures, but at the most extreme and most vehement?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: In that every one will agree.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the obvious instances of the greatest pleasures, as we have often said, are the pleasures of the body?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are they felt by us to be or become greater, when we are sick or when we are in health? And here we must be careful in our answer, or we shall come to grief.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How will that be?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, because we might be tempted to answer, 'When we are in health.'

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, that is the natural answer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but are not those pleasures the greatest of which mankind have the greatest desires?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do not people who are in a fever, or any similar illness, feel cold or thirst or other bodily affections more intensely? Am I not right in saying that they have a deeper want and greater pleasure in the satisfaction of their want?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is obvious as soon as it is said.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, shall we not be right in saying, that if a person would wish to see the greatest pleasures he ought to go and look, not at health, but at disease? And here you must distinguish:--do not imagine that I mean to ask whether those who are very ill have more pleasures than those who are well, but understand that I am speaking of the magnitude of pleasure; I want to know where pleasures are found to be most intense. For, as I say, we have to discover what is pleasure, and what they mean by pleasure who deny her very existence.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I think I follow you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You will soon have a better opportunity of showing whether you do or not, Protarchus. Answer now, and tell me whether you see, I will not say more, but more intense and excessive pleasures in wantonness than in temperance? Reflect before you speak.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I understand you, and see that there is a great difference between them; the temperate are restrained by the wise man's aphorism of 'Never too much,' which is their rule, but excess of pleasure possessing the minds of fools and wantons becomes madness and makes them shout with delight.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very good, and if this be true, then the greatest pleasures and pains will clearly be found in some vicious state of soul and body, and not in a virtuous state.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And ought we not to select some of these for examination, and see what makes them the greatest?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: To be sure we ought.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Take the case of the pleasures which arise out of certain disorders.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What disorders?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The pleasures of unseemly disorders, which our severe friends utterly detest.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What pleasures?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Such, for example, as the relief of itching and other ailments by scratching, which is the only remedy required. For what in Heaven's name is the feeling to be called which is thus produced in us?--Pleasure or pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: A villainous mixture of some kind, Socrates, I should say.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I did not introduce the argument, O Protarchus, with any personal reference to Philebus, but because, without the consideration of these and similar pleasures, we shall not be able to determine the point at issue.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Then we had better proceed to analyze this family of pleasures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean the pleasures which are mingled with pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There are some mixtures which are of the body, and only in the body, and others which are of the soul, and only in the soul; while there are other mixtures of pleasures with pains, common both to soul and body, which in their composite state are called sometimes pleasures and sometimes pains.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Whenever, in the restoration or in the derangement of nature, a man experiences two opposite feelings; for example, when he is cold and is growing warm, or again, when he is hot and is becoming cool, and he wants to have the one and be rid of the other;--the sweet has a bitter, as the common saying is, and both together fasten upon him and create irritation and in time drive him to distraction.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That description is very true to nature.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in these sorts of mixtures the pleasures and pains are sometimes equal, and sometimes one or other of them predominates?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Of cases in which the pain exceeds the pleasure, an example is afforded by itching, of which we were just now speaking, and by the tingling which we feel when the boiling and fiery element is within, and the rubbing and motion only relieves the surface, and does not reach the parts affected; then if you put them to the fire, and as a last resort apply cold to them, you may often produce the most intense pleasure or pain in the inner parts, which contrasts and mingles with the pain or pleasure, as the case may be, of the outer parts; and this is due to the forcible separation of what is united, or to the union of what is separated, and to the juxtaposition of pleasure and pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Sometimes the element of pleasure prevails in a man, and the slight undercurrent of pain makes him tingle, and causes a gentle irritation; or again, the excessive infusion of pleasure creates an excitement in him,--he even leaps for joy, he assumes all sorts of attitudes, he changes all manner of colours, he gasps for breath, and is quite amazed, and utters the most irrational exclamations.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, indeed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He will say of himself, and others will say of him, that he is dying with these delights; and the more dissipated and good-for-nothing he is, the more vehemently he pursues them in every way; of all pleasures he declares them to be the greatest; and he reckons him who lives in the most constant enjoyment of them to be the happiest of mankind.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That, Socrates, is a very true description of the opinions of the majority about pleasures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, Protarchus, quite true of the mixed pleasures, which arise out of the communion of external and internal sensations in the body; there are also cases in which the mind contributes an opposite element to the body, whether of pleasure or pain, and the two unite and form one mixture. Concerning these I have already remarked, that when a man is empty he desires to be full, and has pleasure in hope and pain in vacuity. But now I must further add what I omitted before, that in all these and similar emotions in which body and mind are opposed (and they are innumerable), pleasure and pain coalesce in one.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I believe that to be quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There still remains one other sort of admixture of pleasures and pains.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The union which, as we were saying, the mind often experiences of purely mental feelings.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Why, do we not speak of anger, fear, desire, sorrow, love, emulation, envy, and the like, as pains which belong to the soul only?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And shall we not find them also full of the most wonderful pleasures? need I remind you of the anger 'Which stirs even a wise man to violence, And is sweeter than honey and the honeycomb?' And you remember how pleasures mingle with pains in lamentation and bereavement?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, there is a natural connexion between them.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And you remember also how at the sight of tragedies the spectators smile through their tears?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly I do.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are you aware that even at a comedy the soul experiences a mixed feeling of pain and pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I do not quite understand you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I admit, Protarchus, that there is some difficulty in recognizing this mixture of feelings at a comedy.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: There is, I think.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the greater the obscurity of the case the more desirable is the examination of it, because the difficulty in detecting other cases of mixed pleasures and pains will be less.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have just mentioned envy; would you not call that a pain of the soul?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet the envious man finds something in the misfortunes of his neighbours at which he is pleased?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And ignorance, and what is termed clownishness, are surely an evil?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: From these considerations learn to know the nature of the ridiculous.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Explain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The ridiculous is in short the specific name which is used to describe the vicious form of a certain habit; and of vice in general it is that kind which is most at variance with the inscription at Delphi.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You mean, Socrates, 'Know thyself.'

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I do; and the opposite would be, 'Know not thyself.'

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now, O Protarchus, try to divide this into three.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Indeed I am afraid that I cannot.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you mean to say that I must make the division for you?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, and what is more, I beg that you will.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Are there not three ways in which ignorance of self may be shown?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What are they?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In the first place, about money; the ignorant may fancy himself richer than he is.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, that is a very common error.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And still more often he will fancy that he is taller or fairer than he is, or that he has some other advantage of person which he really has not.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet surely by far the greatest number err about the goods of the mind; they imagine themselves to be much better men than they are.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, that is by far the commonest delusion.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And of all the virtues, is not wisdom the one which the mass of mankind are always claiming, and which most arouses in them a spirit of contention and lying conceit of wisdom?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And may not all this be truly called an evil condition?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very evil.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But we must pursue the division a step further, Protarchus, if we would see in envy of the childish sort a singular mixture of pleasure and pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How can we make the further division which you suggest?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: All who are silly enough to entertain this lying conceit of themselves may of course be divided, like the rest of mankind, into two classes--one having power and might; and the other the reverse.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let this, then, be the principle of division; those of them who are weak and unable to revenge themselves, when they are laughed at, may be truly called ridiculous, but those who can defend themselves may be more truly described as strong and formidable; for ignorance in the powerful is hateful and horrible, because hurtful to others both in reality and in fiction, but powerless ignorance may be reckoned, and in truth is, ridiculous.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is very true, but I do not as yet see where is the admixture of pleasures and pains.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, then, let us examine the nature of envy.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Proceed.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is not envy an unrighteous pleasure, and also an unrighteous pain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is nothing envious or wrong in rejoicing at the misfortunes of enemies?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But to feel joy instead of sorrow at the sight of our friends' misfortunes--is not that wrong?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Undoubtedly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Did we not say that ignorance was always an evil?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the three kinds of vain conceit in our friends which we enumerated--the vain conceit of beauty, of wisdom, and of wealth, are ridiculous if they are weak, and detestable when they are powerful: May we not say, as I was saying before, that our friends who are in this state of mind, when harmless to others, are simply ridiculous?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: They are ridiculous.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do we not acknowledge this ignorance of theirs to be a misfortune?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And do we feel pain or pleasure in laughing at it?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly we feel pleasure.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And was not envy the source of this pleasure which we feel at the misfortunes of friends?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the argument shows that when we laugh at the folly of our friends, pleasure, in mingling with envy, mingles with pain, for envy has been acknowledged by us to be mental pain, and laughter is pleasant; and so we envy and laugh at the same instant.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the argument implies that there are combinations of pleasure and pain in lamentations, and in tragedy and comedy, not only on the stage, but on the greater stage of human life; and so in endless other cases.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I do not see how any one can deny what you say, Socrates, however eager he may be to assert the opposite opinion.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mentioned anger, desire, sorrow, fear, love, emulation, envy, and similar emotions, as examples in which we should find a mixture of the two elements so often named; did I not?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We may observe that our conclusions hitherto have had reference only to sorrow and envy and anger.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then many other cases still remain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And why do you suppose me to have pointed out to you the admixture which takes place in comedy? Why but to convince you that there was no difficulty in showing the mixed nature of fear and love and similar affections; and I thought that when I had given you the illustration, you would have let me off, and have acknowledged as a general truth that the body without the soul, and the soul without the body, as well as the two united, are susceptible of all sorts of admixtures of pleasures and pains; and so further discussion would have been unnecessary. And now I want to know whether I may depart; or will you keep me here until midnight? I fancy that I may obtain my release without many words;--if I promise that to-morrow I will give you an account of all these cases. But at present I would rather sail in another direction, and go to other matters which remain to be settled, before the judgment can be given which Philebus demands.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good, Socrates; in what remains take your own course.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then after the mixed pleasures the unmixed should have their turn; this is the natural and necessary order.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Excellent.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: These, in turn, then, I will now endeavour to indicate; for with the maintainers of the opinion that all pleasures are a cessation of pain, I do not agree, but, as I was saying, I use them as witnesses, that there are pleasures which seem only and are not, and there are others again which have great power and appear in many forms, yet are intermingled with pains, and are partly alleviations of agony and distress, both of body and mind.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Then what pleasures, Socrates, should we be right in conceiving to be true?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: True pleasures are those which are given by beauty of colour and form, and most of those which arise from smells; those of sound, again, and in general those of which the want is painless and unconscious, and of which the fruition is palpable to sense and pleasant and unalloyed with pain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Once more, Socrates, I must ask what you mean.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: My meaning is certainly not obvious, and I will endeavour to be plainer. I do not mean by beauty of form such beauty as that of animals or pictures, which the many would suppose to be my meaning; but, says the argument, understand me to mean straight lines and circles, and the plane or solid figures which are formed out of them by turning-lathes and rulers and measurers of angles; for these I affirm to be not only relatively beautiful, like other things, but they are eternally and absolutely beautiful, and they have peculiar pleasures, quite unlike the pleasures of scratching. And there are colours which are of the same character, and have similar pleasures; now do you understand my meaning?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I am trying to understand, Socrates, and I hope that you will try to make your meaning clearer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When sounds are smooth and clear, and have a single pure tone, then I mean to say that they are not relatively but absolutely beautiful, and have natural pleasures associated with them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes, there are such pleasures.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The pleasures of smell are of a less ethereal sort, but they have no necessary admixture of pain; and all pleasures, however and wherever experienced, which are unattended by pains, I assign to an analogous class. Here then are two kinds of pleasures.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: To these may be added the pleasures of knowledge, if no hunger of knowledge and no pain caused by such hunger precede them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: And this is the case.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Well, but if a man who is full of knowledge loses his knowledge, are there not pains of forgetting?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Not necessarily, but there may be times of reflection, when he feels grief at the loss of his knowledge.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes, my friend, but at present we are enumerating only the natural perceptions, and have nothing to do with reflection.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: In that case you are right in saying that the loss of knowledge is not attended with pain.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: These pleasures of knowledge, then, are unmixed with pain; and they are not the pleasures of the many but of a very few.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now, having fairly separated the pure pleasures and those which may be rightly termed impure, let us further add to our description of them, that the pleasures which are in excess have no measure, but that those which are not in excess have measure; the great, the excessive, whether more or less frequent, we shall be right in referring to the class of the infinite, and of the more and less, which pours through body and soul alike; and the others we shall refer to the class which has measure.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite right, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Still there is something more to be considered about pleasures.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: When you speak of purity and clearness, or of excess, abundance, greatness and sufficiency, in what relation do these terms stand to truth?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Why do you ask, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Because, Protarchus, I should wish to test pleasure and knowledge in every possible way, in order that if there be a pure and impure element in either of them, I may present the pure element for judgment, and then they will be more easily judged of by you and by me and by all of us.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us investigate all the pure kinds; first selecting for consideration a single instance.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What instance shall we select?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Suppose that we first of all take whiteness.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: How can there be purity in whiteness, and what purity? Is that purest which is greatest or most in quantity, or that which is most unadulterated and freest from any admixture of other colours?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly that which is most unadulterated.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: True, Protarchus; and so the purest white, and not the greatest or largest in quantity, is to be deemed truest and most beautiful?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And we shall be quite right in saying that a little pure white is whiter and fairer and truer than a great deal that is mixed.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Perfectly right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is no need of adducing many similar examples in illustration of the argument about pleasure; one such is sufficient to prove to us that a small pleasure or a small amount of pleasure, if pure or unalloyed with pain, is always pleasanter and truer and fairer than a great pleasure or a great amount of pleasure of another kind.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Assuredly; and the instance you have given is quite sufficient.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But what do you say of another question:--have we not heard that pleasure is always a generation, and has no true being? Do not certain ingenious philosophers teach this doctrine, and ought not we to be grateful to them?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What do they mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I will explain to you, my dear Protarchus, what they mean, by putting a question.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Ask, and I will answer.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I assume that there are two natures, one self-existent, and the other ever in want of something.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What manner of natures are they?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The one majestic ever, the other inferior.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You speak riddles.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You have seen loves good and fair, and also brave lovers of them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I should think so.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Search the universe for two terms which are like these two and are present everywhere.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yet a third time I must say, Be a little plainer, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is no difficulty, Protarchus; the argument is only in play, and insinuates that some things are for the sake of something else (relatives), and that other things are the ends to which the former class subserve (absolutes).

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Your many repetitions make me slow to understand.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: As the argument proceeds, my boy, I dare say that the meaning will become clearer.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very likely.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Here are two new principles.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What are they?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: One is the generation of all things, and the other is essence.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I readily accept from you both generation and essence.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Very right; and would you say that generation is for the sake of essence, or essence for the sake of generation?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: You want to know whether that which is called essence is, properly speaking, for the sake of generation?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: By the gods, I wish that you would repeat your question.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean, O my Protarchus, to ask whether you would tell me that ship-building is for the sake of ships, or ships for the sake of ship-building? and in all similar cases I should ask the same question.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Why do you not answer yourself, Socrates?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I have no objection, but you must take your part.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: My answer is, that all things instrumental, remedial, material, are given to us with a view to generation, and that each generation is relative to, or for the sake of, some being or essence, and that the whole of generation is relative to the whole of essence.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Assuredly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then pleasure, being a generation, must surely be for the sake of some essence?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And that for the sake of which something else is done must be placed in the class of good, and that which is done for the sake of something else, in some other class, my good friend.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then pleasure, being a generation, will be rightly placed in some other class than that of good?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Quite right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then, as I said at first, we ought to be very grateful to him who first pointed out that pleasure was a generation only, and had no true being at all; for he is clearly one who laughs at the notion of pleasure being a good.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Assuredly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And he would surely laugh also at those who make generation their highest end.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of whom are you speaking, and what do they mean?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I am speaking of those who when they are cured of hunger or thirst or any other defect by some process of generation are delighted at the process as if it were pleasure; and they say that they would not wish to live without these and other feelings of a like kind which might be mentioned.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is certainly what they appear to think.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And is not destruction universally admitted to be the opposite of generation?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then he who chooses thus, would choose generation and destruction rather than that third sort of life, in which, as we were saying, was neither pleasure nor pain, but only the purest possible thought.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: He who would make us believe pleasure to be a good is involved in great absurdities, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Great, indeed; and there is yet another of them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Is there not an absurdity in arguing that there is nothing good or noble in the body, or in anything else, but that good is in the soul only, and that the only good of the soul is pleasure; and that courage or temperance or understanding, or any other good of the soul, is not really a good?--and is there not yet a further absurdity in our being compelled to say that he who has a feeling of pain and not of pleasure is bad at the time when he is suffering pain, even though he be the best of men; and again, that he who has a feeling of pleasure, in so far as he is pleased at the time when he is pleased, in that degree excels in virtue?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Nothing, Socrates, can be more irrational than all this.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now, having subjected pleasure to every sort of test, let us not appear to be too sparing of mind and knowledge: let us ring their metal bravely, and see if there be unsoundness in any part, until we have found out what in them is of the purest nature; and then the truest elements both of pleasure and knowledge may be brought up for judgment.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Knowledge has two parts,--the one productive, and the other educational?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And in the productive or handicraft arts, is not one part more akin to knowledge, and the other less; and may not the one part be regarded as the pure, and the other as the impure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us separate the superior or dominant elements in each of them.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What are they, and how do you separate them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: I mean to say, that if arithmetic, mensuration, and weighing be taken away from any art, that which remains will not be much.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Not much, certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The rest will be only conjecture, and the better use of the senses which is given by experience and practice, in addition to a certain power of guessing, which is commonly called art, and is perfected by attention and pains.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Nothing more, assuredly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Music, for instance, is full of this empiricism; for sounds are harmonized, not by measure, but by skilful conjecture; the music of the flute is always trying to guess the pitch of each vibrating note, and is therefore mixed up with much that is doubtful and has little which is certain.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And the same will be found to hold good of medicine and husbandry and piloting and generalship.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The art of the builder, on the other hand, which uses a number of measures and instruments, attains by their help to a greater degree of accuracy than the other arts.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In ship-building and house-building, and in other branches of the art of carpentering, the builder has his rule, lathe, compass, line, and a most ingenious machine for straightening wood.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then now let us divide the arts of which we were speaking into two kinds,--the arts which, like music, are less exact in their results, and those which, like carpentering, are more exact.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Let us make that division.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Of the latter class, the most exact of all are those which we just now spoke of as primary.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I see that you mean arithmetic, and the kindred arts of weighing and measuring.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Certainly, Protarchus; but are not these also distinguishable into two kinds?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What are the two kinds?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In the first place, arithmetic is of two kinds, one of which is popular, and the other philosophical.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How would you distinguish them?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: There is a wide difference between them, Protarchus; some arithmeticians reckon unequal units; as for example, two armies, two oxen, two very large things or two very small things. The party who are opposed to them insist that every unit in ten thousand must be the same as every other unit.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Undoubtedly there is, as you say, a great difference among the votaries of the science; and there may be reasonably supposed to be two sorts of arithmetic.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And when we compare the art of mensuration which is used in building with philosophical geometry, or the art of computation which is used in trading with exact calculation, shall we say of either of the pairs that it is one or two?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: On the analogy of what has preceded, I should be of opinion that they were severally two.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Right; but do you understand why I have discussed the subject?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I think so, but I should like to be told by you.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: The argument has all along been seeking a parallel to pleasure, and true to that original design, has gone on to ask whether one sort of knowledge is purer than another, as one pleasure is purer than another.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Clearly; that was the intention.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And has not the argument in what has preceded, already shown that the arts have different provinces, and vary in their degrees of certainty?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And just now did not the argument first designate a particular art by a common term, thus making us believe in the unity of that art; and then again, as if speaking of two different things, proceed to enquire whether the art as pursed by philosophers, or as pursued by non-philosophers, has more of certainty and purity?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is the very question which the argument is asking.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And how, Protarchus, shall we answer the enquiry?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: O Socrates, we have reached a point at which the difference of clearness in different kinds of knowledge is enormous.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then the answer will be the easier.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly; and let us say in reply, that those arts into which arithmetic and mensuration enter, far surpass all others; and that of these the arts or sciences which are animated by the pure philosophic impulse are infinitely superior in accuracy and truth.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then this is your judgment; and this is the answer which, upon your authority, we will give to all masters of the art of misinterpretation?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What answer?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: That there are two arts of arithmetic, and two of mensuration; and also several other arts which in like manner have this double nature, and yet only one name.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Let us boldly return this answer to the masters of whom you speak, Socrates, and hope for good luck.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: We have explained what we term the most exact arts or sciences.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And yet, Protarchus, dialectic will refuse to acknowledge us, if we do not award to her the first place.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: And pray, what is dialectic?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Clearly the science which has to do with all that knowledge of which we are now speaking; for I am sure that all men who have a grain of intelligence will admit that the knowledge which has to do with being and reality, and sameness and unchangeableness, is by far the truest of all. But how would you decide this question, Protarchus?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I have often heard Gorgias maintain, Socrates, that the art of persuasion far surpassed every other; this, as he says, is by far the best of them all, for to it all things submit, not by compulsion, but of their own free will. Now, I should not like to quarrel either with you or with him.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: You mean to say that you would like to desert, if you were not ashamed?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: As you please.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: May I not have led you into a misapprehension?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Dear Protarchus, I never asked which was the greatest or best or usefullest of arts or sciences, but which had clearness and accuracy, and the greatest amount of truth, however humble and little useful an art. And as for Gorgias, if you do not deny that his art has the advantage in usefulness to mankind, he will not quarrel with you for saying that the study of which I am speaking is superior in this particular of essential truth; as in the comparison of white colours, a little whiteness, if that little be only pure, was said to be superior in truth to a great mass which is impure. And now let us give our best attention and consider well, not the comparative use or reputation of the sciences, but the power or faculty, if there be such, which the soul has of loving the truth, and of doing all things for the sake of it; let us search into the pure element of mind and intelligence, and then we shall be able to say whether the science of which I have been speaking is most likely to possess the faculty, or whether there be some other which has higher claims.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Well, I have been considering, and I can hardly think that any other science or art has a firmer grasp of the truth than this.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Do you say so because you observe that the arts in general and those engaged in them make use of opinion, and are resolutely engaged in the investigation of matters of opinion? Even he who supposes himself to be occupied with nature is really occupied with the things of this world, how created, how acting or acted upon. Is not this the sort of enquiry in which his life is spent?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: He is labouring, not after eternal being, but about things which are becoming, or which will or have become.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And can we say that any of these things which neither are nor have been nor will be unchangeable, when judged by the strict rule of truth ever become certain?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: How can anything fixed be concerned with that which has no fixedness?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: How indeed?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Then mind and science when employed about such changing things do not attain the highest truth?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: I should imagine not.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now let us bid farewell, a long farewell, to you or me or Philebus or Gorgias, and urge on behalf of the argument a single point.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: What point?

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: Let us say that the stable and pure and true and unalloyed has to do with the things which are eternal and unchangeable and unmixed, or if not, at any rate what is most akin to them has; and that all other things are to be placed in a second or inferior class.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And of the names expressing cognition, ought not the fairest to be given to the fairest things?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: That is natural.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And are not mind and wisdom the names which are to be honoured most?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And these names may be said to have their truest and most exact application when the mind is engaged in the contemplation of true being?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And these were the names which I adduced of the rivals of pleasure?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Very true, Socrates.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: In the next place, as to the mixture, here are the ingredients, pleasure and wisdom, and we may be compared to artists who have their materials ready to their hands.

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: And now we must begin to mix them?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: By all means.

Speaker: SOCRATES
Dialogue: But had we not better have a preliminary word and refresh our memories?

Speaker: PROTARCHUS
Dialogue: Of what?

Speaker: SOCRATES
