Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then he who says 'not something' must say absolutely nothing.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most assuredly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And as we cannot admit that a man speaks and says nothing, he who says 'not-being' does not speak at all.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: The difficulty of the argument can no further go.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Not yet, my friend, is the time for such a word; for there still remains of all perplexities the first and greatest, touching the very foundation of the matter.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean? Do not be afraid to speak.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: To that which is, may be attributed some other thing which is?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But can anything which is, be attributed to that which is not?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Impossible.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And all number is to be reckoned among things which are?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, surely number, if anything, has a real existence.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we must not attempt to attribute to not-being number either in the singular or plural?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: The argument implies that we should be wrong in doing so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But how can a man either express in words or even conceive in thought things which are not or a thing which is not without number?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How indeed?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When we speak of things which are not, are we not attributing plurality to not-being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But, on the other hand, when we say 'what is not,' do we not attribute unity?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Manifestly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Nevertheless, we maintain that you may not and ought not to attribute being to not-being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Do you see, then, that not-being in itself can neither be spoken, uttered, or thought, but that it is unthinkable, unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But, if so, I was wrong in telling you just now that the difficulty which was coming is the greatest of all.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What! is there a greater still behind?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Well, I am surprised, after what has been said already, that you do not see the difficulty in which he who would refute the notion of not-being is involved. For he is compelled to contradict himself as soon as he makes the attempt.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean? Speak more clearly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Do not expect clearness from me. For I, who maintain that not-being has no part either in the one or many, just now spoke and am still speaking of not-being as one; for I say 'not-being.' Do you understand?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And a little while ago I said that not-being is unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable: do you follow?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I do after a fashion.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When I introduced the word 'is,' did I not contradict what I said before?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Clearly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And in using the singular verb, did I not speak of not-being as one?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And when I spoke of not-being as indescribable and unspeakable and unutterable, in using each of these words in the singular, did I not refer to not-being as one?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet we say that, strictly speaking, it should not be defined as one or many, and should not even be called 'it,' for the use of the word 'it' would imply a form of unity.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: How, then, can any one put any faith in me? For now, as always, I am unequal to the refutation of not-being. And therefore, as I was saying, do not look to me for the right way of speaking about not-being; but come, let us try the experiment with you.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Make a noble effort, as becomes youth, and endeavour with all your might to speak of not-being in a right manner, without introducing into it either existence or unity or plurality.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: It would be a strange boldness in me which would attempt the task when I see you thus discomfited.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Say no more of ourselves; but until we find some one or other who can speak of not-being without number, we must acknowledge that the Sophist is a clever rogue who will not be got out of his hole.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And if we say to him that he professes an art of making appearances, he will grapple with us and retort our argument upon ourselves; and when we call him an image-maker he will say, 'Pray what do you mean at all by an image?'--and I should like to know, Theaetetus, how we can possibly answer the younker's question?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: We shall doubtless tell him of the images which are reflected in water or in mirrors; also of sculptures, pictures, and other duplicates.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I see, Theaetetus, that you have never made the acquaintance of the Sophist.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why do you think so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: He will make believe to have his eyes shut, or to have none.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When you tell him of something existing in a mirror, or in sculpture, and address him as though he had eyes, he will laugh you to scorn, and will pretend that he knows nothing of mirrors and streams, or of sight at all; he will say that he is asking about an idea.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What can he mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The common notion pervading all these objects, which you speak of as many, and yet call by the single name of image, as though it were the unity under which they were all included. How will you maintain your ground against him?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How, Stranger, can I describe an image except as something fashioned in the likeness of the true?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And do you mean this something to be some other true thing, or what do you mean?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not another true thing, but only a resemblance.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And you mean by true that which really is?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the not true is that which is the opposite of the true?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: A resemblance, then, is not really real, if, as you say, not true?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Nay, but it is in a certain sense.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You mean to say, not in a true sense?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes; it is in reality only an image.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then what we call an image is in reality really unreal.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: In what a strange complication of being and not-being we are involved!

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Strange! I should think so. See how, by his reciprocation of opposites, the many-headed Sophist has compelled us, quite against our will, to admit the existence of not-being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, indeed, I see.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The difficulty is how to define his art without falling into a contradiction.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How do you mean? And where does the danger lie?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When we say that he deceives us with an illusion, and that his art is illusory, do we mean that our soul is led by his art to think falsely, or what do we mean?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There is nothing else to be said.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Again, false opinion is that form of opinion which thinks the opposite of the truth:--You would assent?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You mean to say that false opinion thinks what is not?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Does false opinion think that things which are not are not, or that in a certain sense they are?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Things that are not must be imagined to exist in a certain sense, if any degree of falsehood is to be possible.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And does not false opinion also think that things which most certainly exist do not exist at all?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And here, again, is falsehood?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Falsehood--yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And in like manner, a false proposition will be deemed to be one which asserts the non-existence of things which are, and the existence of things which are not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There is no other way in which a false proposition can arise.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: There is not; but the Sophist will deny these statements. And indeed how can any rational man assent to them, when the very expressions which we have just used were before acknowledged by us to be unutterable, unspeakable, indescribable, unthinkable? Do you see his point, Theaetetus?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course he will say that we are contradicting ourselves when we hazard the assertion, that falsehood exists in opinion and in words; for in maintaining this, we are compelled over and over again to assert being of not-being, which we admitted just now to be an utter impossibility.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: How well you remember! And now it is high time to hold a consultation as to what we ought to do about the Sophist; for if we persist in looking for him in the class of false workers and magicians, you see that the handles for objection and the difficulties which will arise are very numerous and obvious.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: They are indeed.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We have gone through but a very small portion of them, and they are really infinite.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: If that is the case, we cannot possibly catch the Sophist.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Shall we then be so faint-hearted as to give him up?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not, I should say, if we can get the slightest hold upon him.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Will you then forgive me, and, as your words imply, not be altogether displeased if I flinch a little from the grasp of such a sturdy argument?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure I will.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I have a yet more urgent request to make.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Which is--?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: That you will promise not to regard me as a parricide.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And why?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Because, in self-defence, I must test the philosophy of my father Parmenides, and try to prove by main force that in a certain sense not-being is, and that being, on the other hand, is not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Some attempt of the kind is clearly needed.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yes, a blind man, as they say, might see that, and, unless these questions are decided in one way or another, no one when he speaks of false words, or false opinion, or idols, or images, or imitations, or appearances, or about the arts which are concerned with them; can avoid falling into ridiculous contradictions.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And therefore I must venture to lay hands on my father's argument; for if I am to be over-scrupulous, I shall have to give the matter up.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Nothing in the world should ever induce us to do so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I have a third little request which I wish to make.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You heard me say what I have always felt and still feel--that I have no heart for this argument?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I tremble at the thought of what I have said, and expect that you will deem me mad, when you hear of my sudden changes and shiftings; let me therefore observe, that I am examining the question entirely out of regard for you.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There is no reason for you to fear that I shall impute any impropriety to you, if you attempt this refutation and proof; take heart, therefore, and proceed.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And where shall I begin the perilous enterprise? I think that the road which I must take is--

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Which?--Let me hear.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I think that we had better, first of all, consider the points which at present are regarded as self-evident, lest we may have fallen into some confusion, and be too ready to assent to one another, fancying that we are quite clear about them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Say more distinctly what you mean.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I think that Parmenides, and all ever yet undertook to determine the number and nature of existences, talked to us in rather a light and easy strain.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: As if we had been children, to whom they repeated each his own mythus or story;--one said that there were three principles, and that at one time there was war between certain of them; and then again there was peace, and they were married and begat children, and brought them up; and another spoke of two principles,--a moist and a dry, or a hot and a cold, and made them marry and cohabit. The Eleatics, however, in our part of the world, say that all things are many in name, but in nature one; this is their mythus, which goes back to Xenophanes, and is even older. Then there are Ionian, and in more recent times Sicilian muses, who have arrived at the conclusion that to unite the two principles is safer, and to say that being is one and many, and that these are held together by enmity and friendship, ever parting, ever meeting, as the severer Muses assert, while the gentler ones do not insist on the perpetual strife and peace, but admit a relaxation and alternation of them; peace and unity sometimes prevailing under the sway of Aphrodite, and then again plurality and war, by reason of a principle of strife. Whether any of them spoke the truth in all this is hard to determine; besides, antiquity and famous men should have reverence, and not be liable to accusations so serious. Yet one thing may be said of them without offence--

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What thing?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: That they went on their several ways disdaining to notice people like ourselves; they did not care whether they took us with them, or left us behind them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I mean to say, that when they talk of one, two, or more elements, which are or have become or are becoming, or again of heat mingling with cold, assuming in some other part of their works separations and mixtures,--tell me, Theaetetus, do you understand what they mean by these expressions? When I was a younger man, I used to fancy that I understood quite well what was meant by the term 'not-being,' which is our present subject of dispute; and now you see in what a fix we are about it.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And very likely we have been getting into the same perplexity about 'being,' and yet may fancy that when anybody utters the word, we understand him quite easily, although we do not know about not-being. But we may be; equally ignorant of both.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I dare say.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the same may be said of all the terms just mentioned.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The consideration of most of them may be deferred; but we had better now discuss the chief captain and leader of them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of what are you speaking? You clearly think that we must first investigate what people mean by the word 'being.'

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You follow close at my heels, Theaetetus. For the right method, I conceive, will be to call into our presence the dualistic philosophers and to interrogate them. 'Come,' we will say, 'Ye, who affirm that hot and cold or any other two principles are the universe, what is this term which you apply to both of them, and what do you mean when you say that both and each of them "are"? How are we to understand the word "are"? Upon your view, are we to suppose that there is a third principle over and above the other two,--three in all, and not two? For clearly you cannot say that one of the two principles is being, and yet attribute being equally to both of them; for, if you did, whichever of the two is identified with being, will comprehend the other; and so they will be one and not two.'

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But perhaps you mean to give the name of 'being' to both of them together?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite likely.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: 'Then, friends,' we shall reply to them, 'the answer is plainly that the two will still be resolved into one.'

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: 'Since, then, we are in a difficulty, please to tell us what you mean, when you speak of being; for there can be no doubt that you always from the first understood your own meaning, whereas we once thought that we understood you, but now we are in a great strait. Please to begin by explaining this matter to us, and let us no longer fancy that we understand you, when we entirely misunderstand you.' There will be no impropriety in our demanding an answer to this question, either of the dualists or of the pluralists?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And what about the assertors of the oneness of the all--must we not endeavour to ascertain from them what they mean by 'being'?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: By all means.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then let them answer this question: One, you say, alone is? 'Yes,' they will reply.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And there is something which you call 'being'?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: 'Yes.'

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And is being the same as one, and do you apply two names to the same thing?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What will be their answer, Stranger?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: It is clear, Theaetetus, that he who asserts the unity of being will find a difficulty in answering this or any other question.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: To admit of two names, and to affirm that there is nothing but unity, is surely ridiculous?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And equally irrational to admit that a name is anything?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: To distinguish the name from the thing, implies duality.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet he who identifies the name with the thing will be compelled to say that it is the name of nothing, or if he says that it is the name of something, even then the name will only be the name of a name, and of nothing else.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the one will turn out to be only one of one, and being absolute unity, will represent a mere name.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And would they say that the whole is other than the one that is, or the same with it?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure they would, and they actually say so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: If being is a whole, as Parmenides sings,-- 'Every way like unto the fullness of a well-rounded sphere, Evenly balanced from the centre on every side, And must needs be neither greater nor less in any way, Neither on this side nor on that--' then being has a centre and extremes, and, having these, must also have parts.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yet that which has parts may have the attribute of unity in all the parts, and in this way being all and a whole, may be one?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But that of which this is the condition cannot be absolute unity?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Because, according to right reason, that which is truly one must be affirmed to be absolutely indivisible.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But this indivisible, if made up of many parts, will contradict reason.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I understand.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Shall we say that being is one and a whole, because it has the attribute of unity? Or shall we say that being is not a whole at all?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is a hard alternative to offer.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Most true; for being, having in a certain sense the attribute of one, is yet proved not to be the same as one, and the all is therefore more than one.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet if being be not a whole, through having the attribute of unity, and there be such a thing as an absolute whole, being lacks something of its own nature?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Upon this view, again, being, having a defect of being, will become not-being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, again, the all becomes more than one, for being and the whole will each have their separate nature.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But if the whole does not exist at all, all the previous difficulties remain the same, and there will be the further difficulty, that besides having no being, being can never have come into being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Because that which comes into being always comes into being as a whole, so that he who does not give whole a place among beings, cannot speak either of essence or generation as existing.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, that certainly appears to be true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Again; how can that which is not a whole have any quantity? For that which is of a certain quantity must necessarily be the whole of that quantity.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And there will be innumerable other points, each of them causing infinite trouble to him who says that being is either one or two.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: The difficulties which are dawning upon us prove this; for one objection connects with another, and they are always involving what has preceded in a greater and worse perplexity.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We are far from having exhausted the more exact thinkers who treat of being and not-being. But let us be content to leave them, and proceed to view those who speak less precisely; and we shall find as the result of all, that the nature of being is quite as difficult to comprehend as that of not-being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Then now we will go to the others.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: There appears to be a sort of war of Giants and Gods going on amongst them; they are fighting with one another about the nature of essence.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Some of them are dragging down all things from heaven and from the unseen to earth, and they literally grasp in their hands rocks and oaks; of these they lay hold, and obstinately maintain, that the things only which can be touched or handled have being or essence, because they define being and body as one, and if any one else says that what is not a body exists they altogether despise him, and will hear of nothing but body.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I have often met with such men, and terrible fellows they are.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And that is the reason why their opponents cautiously defend themselves from above, out of an unseen world, mightily contending that true essence consists of certain intelligible and incorporeal ideas; the bodies of the materialists, which by them are maintained to be the very truth, they break up into little bits by their arguments, and affirm them to be, not essence, but generation and motion. Between the two armies, Theaetetus, there is always an endless conflict raging concerning these matters.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us ask each party in turn, to give an account of that which they call essence.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How shall we get it out of them?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: With those who make being to consist in ideas, there will be less difficulty, for they are civil people enough; but there will be very great difficulty, or rather an absolute impossibility, in getting an opinion out of those who drag everything down to matter. Shall I tell you what we must do?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us, if we can, really improve them; but if this is not possible, let us imagine them to be better than they are, and more willing to answer in accordance with the rules of argument, and then their opinion will be more worth having; for that which better men acknowledge has more weight than that which is acknowledged by inferior men. Moreover we are no respecters of persons, but seekers after truth.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then now, on the supposition that they are improved, let us ask them to state their views, and do you interpret them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let them say whether they would admit that there is such a thing as a mortal animal.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course they would.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And do they not acknowledge this to be a body having a soul?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly they do.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Meaning to say that the soul is something which exists?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And do they not say that one soul is just, and another unjust, and that one soul is wise, and another foolish?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And that the just and wise soul becomes just and wise by the possession of justice and wisdom, and the opposite under opposite circumstances?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, they do.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But surely that which may be present or may be absent will be admitted by them to exist?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, allowing that justice, wisdom, the other virtues, and their opposites exist, as well as a soul in which they inhere, do they affirm any of them to be visible and tangible, or are they all invisible?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: They would say that hardly any of them are visible.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And would they say that they are corporeal?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: They would distinguish: the soul would be said by them to have a body; but as to the other qualities of justice, wisdom, and the like, about which you asked, they would not venture either to deny their existence, or to maintain that they were all corporeal.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Verily, Theaetetus, I perceive a great improvement in them; the real aborigines, children of the dragon's teeth, would have been deterred by no shame at all, but would have obstinately asserted that nothing is which they are not able to squeeze in their hands.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is pretty much their notion.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us push the question; for if they will admit that any, even the smallest particle of being, is incorporeal, it is enough; they must then say what that nature is which is common to both the corporeal and incorporeal, and which they have in their mind's eye when they say of both of them that they 'are.' Perhaps they may be in a difficulty; and if this is the case, there is a possibility that they may accept a notion of ours respecting the nature of being, having nothing of their own to offer.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What is the notion? Tell me, and we shall soon see.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: My notion would be, that anything which possesses any sort of power to affect another, or to be affected by another, if only for a single moment, however trifling the cause and however slight the effect, has real existence; and I hold that the definition of being is simply power.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: They accept your suggestion, having nothing better of their own to offer.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Very good; perhaps we, as well as they, may one day change our minds; but, for the present, this may be regarded as the understanding which is established with them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Agreed.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us now go to the friends of ideas; of their opinions, too, you shall be the interpreter.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: To them we say--You would distinguish essence from generation?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: 'Yes,' they reply.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And you would allow that we participate in generation with the body, and through perception, but we participate with the soul through thought in true essence; and essence you would affirm to be always the same and immutable, whereas generation or becoming varies?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes; that is what we should affirm.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Well, fair sirs, we say to them, what is this participation, which you assert of both? Do you agree with our recent definition?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What definition?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We said that being was an active or passive energy, arising out of a certain power which proceeds from elements meeting with one another. Perhaps your ears, Theaetetus, may fail to catch their answer, which I recognize because I have been accustomed to hear it.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And what is their answer?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: They deny the truth of what we were just now saying to the aborigines about existence.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Any power of doing or suffering in a degree however slight was held by us to be a sufficient definition of being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: They deny this, and say that the power of doing or suffering is confined to becoming, and that neither power is applicable to being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And is there not some truth in what they say?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yes; but our reply will be, that we want to ascertain from them more distinctly, whether they further admit that the soul knows, and that being or essence is known.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There can be no doubt that they say so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And is knowing and being known doing or suffering, or both, or is the one doing and the other suffering, or has neither any share in either?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Clearly, neither has any share in either; for if they say anything else, they will contradict themselves.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I understand; but they will allow that if to know is active, then, of course, to be known is passive. And on this view being, in so far as it is known, is acted upon by knowledge, and is therefore in motion; for that which is in a state of rest cannot be acted upon, as we affirm.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, O heavens, can we ever be made to believe that motion and life and soul and mind are not present with perfect being? Can we imagine that being is devoid of life and mind, and exists in awful unmeaningness an everlasting fixture?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That would be a dreadful thing to admit, Stranger.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But shall we say that has mind and not life?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How is that possible?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Or shall we say that both inhere in perfect being, but that it has no soul which contains them?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And in what other way can it contain them?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Or that being has mind and life and soul, but although endowed with soul remains absolutely unmoved?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: All three suppositions appear to me to be irrational.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Under being, then, we must include motion, and that which is moved.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, Theaetetus, our inference is, that if there is no motion, neither is there any mind anywhere, or about anything or belonging to any one.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet this equally follows, if we grant that all things are in motion--upon this view too mind has no existence.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Do you think that sameness of condition and mode and subject could ever exist without a principle of rest?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Can you see how without them mind could exist, or come into existence anywhere?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And surely contend we must in every possible way against him who would annihilate knowledge and reason and mind, and yet ventures to speak confidently about anything.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, with all our might.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then the philosopher, who has the truest reverence for these qualities, cannot possibly accept the notion of those who say that the whole is at rest, either as unity or in many forms: and he will be utterly deaf to those who assert universal motion. As children say entreatingly 'Give us both,' so he will include both the moveable and immoveable in his definition of being and all.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now, do we seem to have gained a fair notion of being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes truly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Alas, Theaetetus, methinks that we are now only beginning to see the real difficulty of the enquiry into the nature of it.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: O my friend, do you not see that nothing can exceed our ignorance, and yet we fancy that we are saying something good?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I certainly thought that we were; and I do not at all understand how we never found out our desperate case.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Reflect: after having made these admissions, may we not be justly asked the same questions which we ourselves were asking of those who said that all was hot and cold?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What were they? Will you recall them to my mind?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: To be sure I will, and I will remind you of them, by putting the same questions to you which I did to them, and then we shall get on.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Would you not say that rest and motion are in the most entire opposition to one another?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet you would say that both and either of them equally are?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I should.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And when you admit that both or either of them are, do you mean to say that both or either of them are in motion?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Or do you wish to imply that they are both at rest, when you say that they are?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then you conceive of being as some third and distinct nature, under which rest and motion are alike included; and, observing that they both participate in being, you declare that they are.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Truly we seem to have an intimation that being is some third thing, when we say that rest and motion are.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then being is not the combination of rest and motion, but something different from them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: So it would appear.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Being, then, according to its own nature, is neither in motion nor at rest.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is very much the truth.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Where, then, is a man to look for help who would have any clear or fixed notion of being in his mind?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Where, indeed?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I scarcely think that he can look anywhere; for that which is not in motion must be at rest, and again, that which is not at rest must be in motion; but being is placed outside of both these classes. Is this possible?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Utterly impossible.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Here, then, is another thing which we ought to bear in mind.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When we were asked to what we were to assign the appellation of not-being, we were in the greatest difficulty:--do you remember?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And are we not now in as great a difficulty about being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I should say, Stranger, that we are in one which is, if possible, even greater.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then let us acknowledge the difficulty; and as being and not-being are involved in the same perplexity, there is hope that when the one appears more or less distinctly, the other will equally appear; and if we are able to see neither, there may still be a chance of steering our way in between them, without any great discredit.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us enquire, then, how we come to predicate many names of the same thing.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Give an example.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I mean that we speak of man, for example, under many names--that we attribute to him colours and forms and magnitudes and virtues and vices, in all of which instances and in ten thousand others we not only speak of him as a man, but also as good, and having numberless other attributes, and in the same way anything else which we originally supposed to be one is described by us as many, and under many names.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And thus we provide a rich feast for tyros, whether young or old; for there is nothing easier than to argue that the one cannot be many, or the many one; and great is their delight in denying that a man is good; for man, they insist, is man and good is good. I dare say that you have met with persons who take an interest in such matters--they are often elderly men, whose meagre sense is thrown into amazement by these discoveries of theirs, which they believe to be the height of wisdom.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly, I have.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, not to exclude any one who has ever speculated at all upon the nature of being, let us put our questions to them as well as to our former friends.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What questions?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Shall we refuse to attribute being to motion and rest, or anything to anything, and assume that they do not mingle, and are incapable of participating in one another? Or shall we gather all into one class of things communicable with one another? Or are some things communicable and others not?--Which of these alternatives, Theaetetus, will they prefer?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I have nothing to answer on their behalf. Suppose that you take all these hypotheses in turn, and see what are the consequences which follow from each of them.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Very good, and first let us assume them to say that nothing is capable of participating in anything else in any respect; in that case rest and motion cannot participate in being at all.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: They cannot.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But would either of them be if not participating in being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then by this admission everything is instantly overturned, as well the doctrine of universal motion as of universal rest, and also the doctrine of those who distribute being into immutable and everlasting kinds; for all these add on a notion of being, some affirming that things 'are' truly in motion, and others that they 'are' truly at rest.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Just so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Again, those who would at one time compound, and at another resolve all things, whether making them into one and out of one creating infinity, or dividing them into finite elements, and forming compounds out of these; whether they suppose the processes of creation to be successive or continuous, would be talking nonsense in all this if there were no admixture.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Most ridiculous of all will the men themselves be who want to carry out the argument and yet forbid us to call anything, because participating in some affection from another, by the name of that other.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Why, because they are compelled to use the words 'to be,' 'apart,' 'from others,' 'in itself,' and ten thousand more, which they cannot give up, but must make the connecting links of discourse; and therefore they do not require to be refuted by others, but their enemy, as the saying is, inhabits the same house with them; they are always carrying about with them an adversary, like the wonderful ventriloquist, Eurycles, who out of their own bellies audibly contradicts them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Precisely so; a very true and exact illustration.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now, if we suppose that all things have the power of communion with one another--what will follow?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Even I can solve that riddle.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why, because motion itself would be at rest, and rest again in motion, if they could be attributed to one another.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But this is utterly impossible.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then only the third hypothesis remains.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: For, surely, either all things have communion with all; or nothing with any other thing; or some things communicate with some things and others not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And two out of these three suppositions have been found to be impossible.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Every one then, who desires to answer truly, will adopt the third and remaining hypothesis of the communion of some with some.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: This communion of some with some may be illustrated by the case of letters; for some letters do not fit each other, while others do.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the vowels, especially, are a sort of bond which pervades all the other letters, so that without a vowel one consonant cannot be joined to another.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But does every one know what letters will unite with what? Or is art required in order to do so?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Art is required.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: What art?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: The art of grammar.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And is not this also true of sounds high and low?--Is not he who has the art to know what sounds mingle, a musician, and he who is ignorant, not a musician?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And we shall find this to be generally true of art or the absence of art.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And as classes are admitted by us in like manner to be some of them capable and others incapable of intermixture, must not he who would rightly show what kinds will unite and what will not, proceed by the help of science in the path of argument? And will he not ask if the connecting links are universal, and so capable of intermixture with all things; and again, in divisions, whether there are not other universal classes, which make them possible?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure he will require science, and, if I am not mistaken, the very greatest of all sciences.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: How are we to call it? By Zeus, have we not lighted unwittingly upon our free and noble science, and in looking for the Sophist have we not entertained the philosopher unawares?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Should we not say that the division according to classes, which neither makes the same other, nor makes other the same, is the business of the dialectical science?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is what we should say.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, surely, he who can divide rightly is able to see clearly one form pervading a scattered multitude, and many different forms contained under one higher form; and again, one form knit together into a single whole and pervading many such wholes, and many forms, existing only in separation and isolation. This is the knowledge of classes which determines where they can have communion with one another and where not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the art of dialectic would be attributed by you only to the philosopher pure and true?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Who but he can be worthy?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: In this region we shall always discover the philosopher, if we look for him; like the Sophist, he is not easily discovered, but for a different reason.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: For what reason?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Because the Sophist runs away into the darkness of not-being, in which he has learned by habit to feel about, and cannot be discovered because of the darkness of the place. Is not that true?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: It seems to be so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the philosopher, always holding converse through reason with the idea of being, is also dark from excess of light; for the souls of the many have no eye which can endure the vision of the divine.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes; that seems to be quite as true as the other.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Well, the philosopher may hereafter be more fully considered by us, if we are disposed; but the Sophist must clearly not be allowed to escape until we have had a good look at him.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Since, then, we are agreed that some classes have a communion with one another, and others not, and some have communion with a few and others with many, and that there is no reason why some should not have universal communion with all, let us now pursue the enquiry, as the argument suggests, not in relation to all ideas, lest the multitude of them should confuse us, but let us select a few of those which are reckoned to be the principal ones, and consider their several natures and their capacity of communion with one another, in order that if we are not able to apprehend with perfect clearness the notions of being and not-being, we may at least not fall short in the consideration of them, so far as they come within the scope of the present enquiry, if peradventure we may be allowed to assert the reality of not-being, and yet escape unscathed.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: We must do so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The most important of all the genera are those which we were just now mentioning--being and rest and motion.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, by far.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And two of these are, as we affirm, incapable of communion with one another.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite incapable.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Whereas being surely has communion with both of them, for both of them are?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: That makes up three of them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And each of them is other than the remaining two, but the same with itself.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But then, what is the meaning of these two words, 'same' and 'other'? Are they two new kinds other than the three, and yet always of necessity intermingling with them, and are we to have five kinds instead of three; or when we speak of the same and other, are we unconsciously speaking of one of the three first kinds?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very likely we are.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But, surely, motion and rest are neither the other nor the same.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Whatever we attribute to motion and rest in common, cannot be either of them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Because motion would be at rest and rest in motion, for either of them, being predicated of both, will compel the other to change into the opposite of its own nature, because partaking of its opposite.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yet they surely both partake of the same and of the other?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we must not assert that motion, any more than rest, is either the same or the other.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: No; we must not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But are we to conceive that being and the same are identical?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Possibly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But if they are identical, then again in saying that motion and rest have being, we should also be saying that they are the same.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Which surely cannot be.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then being and the same cannot be one.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Scarcely.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we may suppose the same to be a fourth class, which is now to be added to the three others.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And shall we call the other a fifth class? Or should we consider being and other to be two names of the same class?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very likely.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But you would agree, if I am not mistaken, that existences are relative as well as absolute?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the other is always relative to other?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But this would not be the case unless being and the other entirely differed; for, if the other, like being, were absolute as well as relative, then there would have been a kind of other which was not other than other. And now we find that what is other must of necessity be what it is in relation to some other.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is the true state of the case.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we must admit the other as the fifth of our selected classes.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the fifth class pervades all classes, for they all differ from one another, not by reason of their own nature, but because they partake of the idea of the other.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then let us now put the case with reference to each of the five.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: First there is motion, which we affirm to be absolutely 'other' than rest: what else can we say?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: It is so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And therefore is not rest.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And yet is, because partaking of being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Again, motion is other than the same?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Just so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And is therefore not the same.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: It is not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yet, surely, motion is the same, because all things partake of the same.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we must admit, and not object to say, that motion is the same and is not the same, for we do not apply the terms 'same' and 'not the same,' in the same sense; but we call it the 'same,' in relation to itself, because partaking of the same; and not the same, because having communion with the other, it is thereby severed from the same, and has become not that but other, and is therefore rightly spoken of as 'not the same.'

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And if absolute motion in any point of view partook of rest, there would be no absurdity in calling motion stationary.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite right,--that is, on the supposition that some classes mingle with one another, and others not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: That such a communion of kinds is according to nature, we had already proved before we arrived at this part of our discussion.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us proceed, then. May we not say that motion is other than the other, having been also proved by us to be other than the same and other than rest?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is certain.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, according to this view, motion is other and also not other?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: What is the next step? Shall we say that motion is other than the three and not other than the fourth,--for we agreed that there are five classes about and in the sphere of which we proposed to make enquiry?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Surely we cannot admit that the number is less than it appeared to be just now.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we may without fear contend that motion is other than being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Without the least fear.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The plain result is that motion, since it partakes of being, really is and also is not?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Nothing can be plainer.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then not-being necessarily exists in the case of motion and of every class; for the nature of the other entering into them all, makes each of them other than being, and so non-existent; and therefore of all of them, in like manner, we may truly say that they are not; and again, inasmuch as they partake of being, that they are and are existent.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: So we may assume.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Every class, then, has plurality of being and infinity of not-being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: So we must infer.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And being itself may be said to be other than the other kinds.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then we may infer that being is not, in respect of as many other things as there are; for not-being these it is itself one, and is not the other things, which are infinite in number.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is not far from the truth.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And we must not quarrel with this result, since it is of the nature of classes to have communion with one another; and if any one denies our present statement [viz., that being is not, etc.], let him first argue with our former conclusion [i.e., respecting the communion of ideas], and then he may proceed to argue with what follows.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Nothing can be fairer.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let me ask you to consider a further question.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What question?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When we speak of not-being, we speak, I suppose, not of something opposed to being, but only different.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When we speak of something as not great, does the expression seem to you to imply what is little any more than what is equal?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly not.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The negative particles, ou and me, when prefixed to words, do not imply opposition, but only difference from the words, or more correctly from the things represented by the words, which follow them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: There is another point to be considered, if you do not object.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The nature of the other appears to me to be divided into fractions like knowledge.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Knowledge, like the other, is one; and yet the various parts of knowledge have each of them their own particular name, and hence there are many arts and kinds of knowledge.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And is not the case the same with the parts of the other, which is also one?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very likely; but will you tell me how?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: There is some part of the other which is opposed to the beautiful?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There is.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Shall we say that this has or has not a name?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: It has; for whatever we call not-beautiful is other than the beautiful, not than something else.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now tell me another thing.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Is the not-beautiful anything but this--an existence parted off from a certain kind of existence, and again from another point of view opposed to an existing something?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then the not-beautiful turns out to be the opposition of being to being?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But upon this view, is the beautiful a more real and the not-beautiful a less real existence?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the not-great may be said to exist, equally with the great?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, in the same way, the just must be placed in the same category with the not-just--the one cannot be said to have any more existence than the other.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The same may be said of other things; seeing that the nature of the other has a real existence, the parts of this nature must equally be supposed to exist.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, as would appear, the opposition of a part of the other, and of a part of being, to one another, is, if I may venture to say so, as truly essence as being itself, and implies not the opposite of being, but only what is other than being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Beyond question.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: What then shall we call it?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Clearly, not-being; and this is the very nature for which the Sophist compelled us to search.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And has not this, as you were saying, as real an existence as any other class? May I not say with confidence that not-being has an assured existence, and a nature of its own? Just as the great was found to be great and the beautiful beautiful, and the not-great not-great, and the not-beautiful not-beautiful, in the same manner not-being has been found to be and is not-being, and is to be reckoned one among the many classes of being. Do you, Theaetetus, still feel any doubt of this?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: None whatever.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Do you observe that our scepticism has carried us beyond the range of Parmenides' prohibition?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: In what?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We have advanced to a further point, and shown him more than he forbad us to investigate.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How is that?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Why, because he says-- 'Not-being never is, and do thou keep thy thoughts from this way of enquiry.'

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, he says so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Whereas, we have not only proved that things which are not are, but we have shown what form of being not-being is; for we have shown that the nature of the other is, and is distributed over all things in their relations to one another, and whatever part of the other is contrasted with being, this is precisely what we have ventured to call not-being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And surely, Stranger, we were quite right.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let not any one say, then, that while affirming the opposition of not-being to being, we still assert the being of not-being; for as to whether there is an opposite of being, to that enquiry we have long said good-bye--it may or may not be, and may or may not be capable of definition. But as touching our present account of not-being, let a man either convince us of error, or, so long as he cannot, he too must say, as we are saying, that there is a communion of classes, and that being, and difference or other, traverse all things and mutually interpenetrate, so that the other partakes of being, and by reason of this participation is, and yet is not that of which it partakes, but other, and being other than being, it is clearly a necessity that not-being should be. And again, being, through partaking of the other, becomes a class other than the remaining classes, and being other than all of them, is not each one of them, and is not all the rest, so that undoubtedly there are thousands upon thousands of cases in which being is not, and all other things, whether regarded individually or collectively, in many respects are, and in many respects are not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And he who is sceptical of this contradiction, must think how he can find something better to say; or if he sees a puzzle, and his pleasure is to drag words this way and that, the argument will prove to him, that he is not making a worthy use of his faculties; for there is no charm in such puzzles, and there is no difficulty in detecting them; but we can tell him of something else the pursuit of which is noble and also difficult.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: A thing of which I have already spoken;--letting alone these puzzles as involving no difficulty, he should be able to follow and criticize in detail every argument, and when a man says that the same is in a manner other, or that other is the same, to understand and refute him from his own point of view, and in the same respect in which he asserts either of these affections. But to show that somehow and in some sense the same is other, or the other same, or the great small, or the like unlike; and to delight in always bringing forward such contradictions, is no real refutation, but is clearly the new-born babe of some one who is only beginning to approach the problem of being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: For certainly, my friend, the attempt to separate all existences from one another is a barbarism and utterly unworthy of an educated or philosophical mind.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The attempt at universal separation is the final annihilation of all reasoning; for only by the union of conceptions with one another do we attain to discourse of reason.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, observe that we were only just in time in making a resistance to such separatists, and compelling them to admit that one thing mingles with another.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Why so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Why, that we might be able to assert discourse to be a kind of being; for if we could not, the worst of all consequences would follow; we should have no philosophy. Moreover, the necessity for determining the nature of discourse presses upon us at this moment; if utterly deprived of it, we could no more hold discourse; and deprived of it we should be if we admitted that there was no admixture of natures at all.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true. But I do not understand why at this moment we must determine the nature of discourse.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Perhaps you will see more clearly by the help of the following explanation.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What explanation?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Not-being has been acknowledged by us to be one among many classes diffused over all being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And thence arises the question, whether not-being mingles with opinion and language.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: If not-being has no part in the proposition, then all things must be true; but if not-being has a part, then false opinion and false speech are possible, for to think or to say what is not--is falsehood, which thus arises in the region of thought and in speech.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That is quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And where there is falsehood surely there must be deceit.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And if there is deceit, then all things must be full of idols and images and fancies.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: To be sure.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Into that region the Sophist, as we said, made his escape, and, when he had got there, denied the very possibility of falsehood; no one, he argued, either conceived or uttered falsehood, inasmuch as not-being did not in any way partake of being.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now, not-being has been shown to partake of being, and therefore he will not continue fighting in this direction, but he will probably say that some ideas partake of not-being, and some not, and that language and opinion are of the non-partaking class; and he will still fight to the death against the existence of the image-making and phantastic art, in which we have placed him, because, as he will say, opinion and language do not partake of not-being, and unless this participation exists, there can be no such thing as falsehood. And, with the view of meeting this evasion, we must begin by enquiring into the nature of language, opinion, and imagination, in order that when we find them we may find also that they have communion with not-being, and, having made out the connexion of them, may thus prove that falsehood exists; and therein we will imprison the Sophist, if he deserves it, or, if not, we will let him go again and look for him in another class.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly, Stranger, there appears to be truth in what was said about the Sophist at first, that he was of a class not easily caught, for he seems to have abundance of defences, which he throws up, and which must every one of them be stormed before we can reach the man himself. And even now, we have with difficulty got through his first defence, which is the not-being of not-being, and lo! here is another; for we have still to show that falsehood exists in the sphere of language and opinion, and there will be another and another line of defence without end.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Any one, Theaetetus, who is able to advance even a little ought to be of good cheer, for what would he who is dispirited at a little progress do, if he were making none at all, or even undergoing a repulse? Such a faint heart, as the proverb says, will never take a city: but now that we have succeeded thus far, the citadel is ours, and what remains is easier.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, as I was saying, let us first of all obtain a conception of language and opinion, in order that we may have clearer grounds for determining, whether not-being has any concern with them, or whether they are both always true, and neither of them ever false.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then, now, let us speak of names, as before we were speaking of ideas and letters; for that is the direction in which the answer may be expected.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: And what is the question at issue about names?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The question at issue is whether all names may be connected with one another, or none, or only some of them.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Clearly the last is true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I understand you to say that words which have a meaning when in sequence may be connected, but that words which have no meaning when in sequence cannot be connected?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What are you saying?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: What I thought that you intended when you gave your assent; for there are two sorts of intimation of being which are given by the voice.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What are they?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: One of them is called nouns, and the other verbs.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Describe them.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: That which denotes action we call a verb.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the other, which is an articulate mark set on those who do the actions, we call a noun.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: A succession of nouns only is not a sentence, any more than of verbs without nouns.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I do not understand you.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I see that when you gave your assent you had something else in your mind. But what I intended to say was, that a mere succession of nouns or of verbs is not discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I mean that words like 'walks,' 'runs,' 'sleeps,' or any other words which denote action, however many of them you string together, do not make discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How can they?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Or, again, when you say 'lion,' 'stag,' 'horse,' or any other words which denote agents--neither in this way of stringing words together do you attain to discourse; for there is no expression of action or inaction, or of the existence of existence or non-existence indicated by the sounds, until verbs are mingled with nouns; then the words fit, and the smallest combination of them forms language, and is the simplest and least form of discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Again I ask, What do you mean?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When any one says 'A man learns,' should you not call this the simplest and least of sentences?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Yes, for he now arrives at the point of giving an intimation about something which is, or is becoming, or has become, or will be. And he not only names, but he does something, by connecting verbs with nouns; and therefore we say that he discourses, and to this connexion of words we give the name of discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And as there are some things which fit one another, and other things which do not fit, so there are some vocal signs which do, and others which do not, combine and form discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: There is another small matter.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: A sentence must and cannot help having a subject.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And must be of a certain quality.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now let us mind what we are about.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: We must do so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: I will repeat a sentence to you in which a thing and an action are combined, by the help of a noun and a verb; and you shall tell me of whom the sentence speaks.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I will, to the best of my power.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: 'Theaetetus sits'--not a very long sentence.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Not very.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Of whom does the sentence speak, and who is the subject? that is what you have to tell.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Of me; I am the subject.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Or this sentence, again--

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What sentence?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: 'Theaetetus, with whom I am now speaking, is flying.'

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: That also is a sentence which will be admitted by every one to speak of me, and to apply to me.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We agreed that every sentence must necessarily have a certain quality.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And what is the quality of each of these two sentences?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: The one, as I imagine, is false, and the other true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The true says what is true about you?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the false says what is other than true?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And therefore speaks of things which are not as if they were?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And say that things are real of you which are not; for, as we were saying, in regard to each thing or person, there is much that is and much that is not.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: The second of the two sentences which related to you was first of all an example of the shortest form consistent with our definition.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, this was implied in recent admission.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And, in the second place, it related to a subject?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Who must be you, and can be nobody else?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Unquestionably.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And it would be no sentence at all if there were no subject, for, as we proved, a sentence which has no subject is impossible.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When other, then, is asserted of you as the same, and not-being as being, such a combination of nouns and verbs is really and truly false discourse.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Most true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And therefore thought, opinion, and imagination are now proved to exist in our minds both as true and false.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You will know better if you first gain a knowledge of what they are, and in what they severally differ from one another.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Give me the knowledge which you would wish me to gain.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Are not thought and speech the same, with this exception, that what is called thought is the unuttered conversation of the soul with herself?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But the stream of thought which flows through the lips and is audible is called speech?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And we know that there exists in speech...

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What exists?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Affirmation.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes, we know it.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: When the affirmation or denial takes Place in silence and in the mind only, have you any other name by which to call it but opinion?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: There can be no other name.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And when opinion is presented, not simply, but in some form of sense, would you not call it imagination?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And seeing that language is true and false, and that thought is the conversation of the soul with herself, and opinion is the end of thinking, and imagination or phantasy is the union of sense and opinion, the inference is that some of them, since they are akin to language, should have an element of falsehood as well as of truth?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Certainly.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Do you perceive, then, that false opinion and speech have been discovered sooner than we expected?--For just now we seemed to be undertaking a task which would never be accomplished.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: I perceive.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Then let us not be discouraged about the future; but now having made this discovery, let us go back to our previous classification.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What classification?

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: We divided image-making into two sorts; the one likeness-making, the other imaginative or phantastic.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And we said that we were uncertain in which we should place the Sophist.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: We did say so.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And our heads began to go round more and more when it was asserted that there is no such thing as an image or idol or appearance, because in no manner or time or place can there ever be such a thing as falsehood.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And now, since there has been shown to be false speech and false opinion, there may be imitations of real existences, and out of this condition of the mind an art of deception may arise.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite possible.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And we have already admitted, in what preceded, that the Sophist was lurking in one of the divisions of the likeness-making art?

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: Let us, then, renew the attempt, and in dividing any class, always take the part to the right, holding fast to that which holds the Sophist, until we have stripped him of all his common properties, and reached his difference or peculiar. Then we may exhibit him in his true nature, first to ourselves and then to kindred dialectical spirits.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very good.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: You may remember that all art was originally divided by us into creative and acquisitive.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: And the Sophist was flitting before us in the acquisitive class, in the subdivisions of hunting, contests, merchandize, and the like.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Very true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: But now that the imitative art has enclosed him, it is clear that we must begin by dividing the art of creation; for imitation is a kind of creation--of images, however, as we affirm, and not of real things.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: Quite true.

Speaker: STRANGER
Dialogue: In the first place, there are two kinds of creation.

Speaker: THEAETETUS
Dialogue: What are they?

Speaker: STRANGER
